Yuru Camp Final Review
In my preliminary review early on I said that there was not a single bad thing I could say about this anime. Now that this series had ended I can say with complete and honest sincerity that that statement hasn't changed one bit. While I do have one minor complaint, which I'll get to later, it's not enough to bring this down this gem of a show.
EASY TO UNDERSTAND
Yuru Camp is an anime that appeals to anyone who enjoys camping and the outdoors in general. Even in an age where just about everything is now digital, the old -fashioned ways of theoutdoors going all the way to the beginning of mankind still resonates with us, and that's exactly what this show does well through its animation. It shows the beauty of the outside world around us and how camping, whether solo or with friends and family, can be memorable experience even when the hard work may be required.


The fact that it also goes into detail of what to do(and not to do) on a camping trip and the things you could do to make it more memorable is also a nice touch for this series. In addition you learn quite a few things, including stuff you never knew about. For example, the Canadian/Scandinavian style camp fire is something is something I never knew about even in my Boy Scout days. As I mentioned before, the level of attention to detail is nothing short of astounding.


EASY TO FOLLOW

While the animation and the attention to detail are to be met with high praise, it's really the characters that make this show so enjoyable to watch. From a energetic air head to a teacher with a drinking habit, they all represents ourselves when it comes to the joy of camping.


The story itself is easy enough for it's a story of a group of young ladies of different backgrounds and personalities who form a special bond by sharing one thing: The Great Outdoors, especially for the first two girls you see in the opening episode.


Nadeshiko herself is one those characters you just can't get enough of for she has a habit of making everything and not just camping more enjoyable that it should be. Even if you find her annoying you can never truly hate her because she'll make you smile and laugh no matter what. Rin Shima on the other hand is more of a kuudere character since she doesn't socialize much at school and she when she goes camping she usually goes solo. 


It's through Nadeshiko's energetic personality that causes Rin to open up more and to explore new things about camping, especially with others instead of just going by herself. Seeing their friendship grow from a simple understanding to a very close bond was the biggest highlight of this show when you consider how different they were when they first met.


The other characters are also fun to watch. Chiaki represents the character who always makes the most out things no matter how difficult or impossible it seems, Aoi being the easy going and always down to Earth character, and Ena is the rich girl who doesn't get out much but is always willing to learn new things, such as camping.


My only real complaint, as I mentioned earlier, is the teacher character. It's not the character herself that was the problem for she was fun to watch with her hilarious drinking habits, it's the way she was handled in this series. I feel that the anime should have brought her into the story an episode or two sooner than they did. The fact that they brought her in so late makes me wonder if she was a last minute addition to the cast for she wasn't given enough time to properly develop. In the end, she ends up being nothing more than a character only put in for comedic purposes and not adding anything to the story. But as I said before this one one complaint isn't enough to bring this show down in any significant manner.


EASY TO CARE ABOUT

As a writer myself, I follow a very specific motto: KEEP IT SIMPLE. And that's exactly what this  anime did. It kept it simple. It would have been very easy for the studio to force in some kind of pointless drama, like one of the characters getting seriously hurt, or forcing in some equally pointless romance, like adding random boys to the cast or teasing us with Yuri(like what Slow Start). But it didn't, instead the studio stayed focused on the what the main premise of this anime is all about, and I cannot thank C-Station enough for the fantastic work they've done for this anime.


CONCLUSION

Yuru Camp gets a solid 10 from me. It may seem like a generous score but its the honest truth. It does bug me, however, that some people find this show boring because nothing "big" happened or that they outright despise it because they think that a show that needs to explain everything is insulting their intelligence. Well, I have three questions for those people.


Why are you here?

What exactly where you expecting out of this anime?

Why the hell do you care so much?


I understand that Slice Of Life anime isn't for everyone, especially for a niche genre such as this but I have to ask: SO WHAT? The fact that they're making such a big issue out of it makes me question their intelligence.


Yuru Camp may not be a masterpiece in a literally sense or a entertaining perspective, but it was never meant to be. It was done to be to be it's own thing. It knew what is was and it shined from start to finish. And that's exactly why I say this anime is a masterpiece. So if any of you ever go camping again, especially with others, watch this anime with because it is a perfect example of what camping is: Creating memories that will last a lifetime.


I'm DirectorK and until next time, stay tuned!

Yuru Camp is  a fully Slice of Life anime whose objective is to give some sort of calming and "healing" effect to the viewers. Some people are accustomed to calling this kinds of anime an iyashikei anime. Yuru Camp does this job very well.
If you don't know what to expect about the story of Yuru Camp, it's basically nothing. Well, not actually nothing, but more of the story not being the main driving point of the show as it doesn't go very far. The setting is girls doing camping in different campsites. Every episode, you should expect the cast to have fun doing camping(and also the journey to the campsite). Some episodes are may not focus on the camping but instead focus on things the girls go that are usually related to camping. Another thing you can find in the episodes is the silly things or conversations the characters do that may put a smile to your face.


What makes Yuru Camp succeeds so well is its use of its art and music. You may find yourself relating the beautiful sceneries drawn to some places in real life. Other than that, you should expect scenes of food being cooked and eaten. Food in this show looks delicious, actually made me feel jealous with the characters (You should be wanting to eat those delicious BBQ as well). The music is what really brings out the relaxing tone of the show. Yuru Camp has a good soundtrack to support its goal and uses it well with the flow.


Watching Yuru Camp every week has been a nice rest from my busy everyday life. A fun and relaxing tone to watch. If you haven't been watching any Slice of Life anime that came out, this one would be a good one to try. The scenery, music, and characters having fun will soothe your soul.


Extra note : It also actually shows some tips for actual camping, spoken by usually a narrator while a character is doing it. It is a nice addition for those who became interested with going camping after watching this.

good character? check
good story? check
amazing background? check
a great music background? hell yes
so whats bad about this anime? none. i love this anime so much. the story is pretty straight up. its basically a story about girl who love to do outdoor activity such as camping. and as the title said "laid-back" this anime really is laid back without any heavy storyline or such, for me this anime is a good choice if you want to laid back and enjoy a light anime after you watch a heavy one (for me i just done code geass). 
and whats so good about this anime that i loveit so much? the music. composed by akiyuki tateyama is an absolute masterpiece. with irish arrangement and a beautiful melody, really fit the scenery this anime shows to us. i never really dig bgm in anime but this one. i love it!


the character are pretty basic its your "cute girl anime" kind of thing but they did a really good job with casting the voice actor because its really fit them and their personality. all in all i love them. and ofc they beautifully designed but its too bad the animation is kinda basic.


but what they lack in character they did a pretty good job with the background. beautifully drawn i have to say. not as heavy as makoto shinkai's work (ofc its only a series) but enough to capture the beautiful scenery (especially the one with mt.Fuji in it). and again the bgm just make it 100 times more beautiful. good job takeyama-san. 


so should you watch it or not? well it depends if you looking for some heavy story filled with plot twist kinda thing this anime isnt for you. but if perhaps you just wanna enjoy some good music and beautiful scenery and ofc, watch 5 cute moe girl who loves camping so much then this show is definitely for you.


so sit down, grab some hot chocolate, coffee or tea. and please enjoy this "laid-back" anime that will probably driven you to go out to do a real camping yourself!

My face when one of the best shows this season that isn't a continuation of a show from last season is a moe slice of life about camping. I don't mean that as a bad point against this show though, this show is actually surprisingly good.
First thing that has to be mentioned is that show looks amazing and the music does a very good job at complementing the mood of the show.
The characters in this show are also a joy to watch while acting a lot more like real people than most shows. Rin and Nadeshiko are especially enjoyable characters with one being a moreintroverted and the other being more outgoing. Their interactions together are never boring to watch and are one of the big reasons why this show is so fun to watch.


Another thing I like about this show is its bit of comedy mixed in and how the narrator seamlessly educates you on a lot of camping related things.


Now you are not going to get any real story from this show but to be honest there really isn't any reason to have one since this is a slice of life show.


Overall, this show is a nice change of pace from most anime and is actually making me want to go camping at some point. I personally give this show an 8/10. This show was a pleasant surprise in a season full of disappointments.

Have you ever played Animal Crossing, Harvest Moon, Stardew Valley? Why do you play them? If I had to guess, it is to escape your everyday life for a little by stepping into someone else's shoes. That is the pleasure that Yuru Camp provides. It's a lovely show, and I recommend it.
Story: 0/10. There isn't really a story. Four girls go to school together and like to camp. That's all, really. As such, I didn't think that it was fair to evaluate the story, since there is little in the way of plot. That's not a bad thing, though. You can be watching it, spaceout while thinking about things, life, etc., and pop back in when something catches your eye without worrying about missing some big story element. It brings the relaxation of camping and solitude to TV. It doesn't reuse the same jokes, so each episode or pair of eps is its own unit, so the show is free of pacing and limitations. The camping tips provided throughout Yuru Camp are both adorable and helpful. 


Art: 10/10. The illustrations are beautiful. Mountain facades, city overlooks, wide open fields with lil critters, all lovely. Each character is visually unique, so it is easy to tell them apart most of the time. Animations are always smooth, not much else to say!


Sound: 10/10. Embracing the peacefulness of the outdoors, the show takes cues from softer bluegrass sounds as most of the ambient music. The tunes are catchy guitar, banjo, fiddle melodies that stick in your head, forcing a smile when they come up. OP is surprisingly exciting, and very upbeat. It reminds me a lot, and I mean A LOT, of One Up Girl, the main theme from Super Mario Odyssey. I'm serious, listen side by side and it's nuts. ED is softer, allowing you to bask in calm merriment at the conclusion of each ep. Make sure you stick around, since a little extra scene plays after each ED, and the stills running behind the track and credits change every now and then.


Characters: 9/10. Super cute and likeable, the main characters are definitely the centerpiece. The older sisters are a little more strange, but they don't appear much. Rin is the quiet loner, not as an outcast but just due to her introverted nature. The others understand and respect this, and it is clear that she is already liked in her school. It's nice to have an introverted protag that isn't the social outsider that we often see. Kagamihara is energetic and silly, but not overbearing. The other two girls in the Outdoors Club are pretty similar so far, both dedicated club members with a passion for food and fun. I hope we get a little more info on the more minor club members, but either way they're still charming. 


Enjoyment: 9/10. I'm surprised at how much I like this show. I didn't know what to expect, I definitely expected drama of some sort. Instead, Yuru Camp a laidback show about enjoying what you have with whoever you want, even if that whoever is just yourself.  I hate the outdoors (heck, I'm on MAL so that should be a given) but Yuru Camp makes me want to take a trip up to the mountains.


Overall: 8/10. Having no story is kind of what gives Yuru Camp the breeze to fly on. It allows total freedom with the adventures the girls take. The girls are funny in a more subtle, chuckle inducing sort of way. The scenery is as beautiful as a sunrise view over Mount Fuji, and the soundtrack really bolsters the splendor of each scene. I look forward to finishing the season!

"Yuru Camp" or "After watching this, where can I camp outdoor near my home?"
     Yuru Camp is the story of a bunch of girls doing camping, sounds wonderful isn't it? The story focuses on two particular characters with opposed personalities: the first one is Nadeshiko, always cheerful and hungry, the second one is Rin, more introverted but as food lover as Nadeshiko. Rin is a regular camper whereas Nadeshiko is a girl who would love to camp. These girls appear to be in the same schools and will be led to share their camping experiences.
     The artis quite simple, not very fluid sometimes, and is very colorful. The camping sites appearing in this anime exist IRL and it's amusing to compare the art of Yuru Camp and a real photography, obviously making us wanting to go camping there. Panoramas hold a great significance in the series and in the art, giving this slice of life tone to the anime.


     Concerning the sound design, the opening and ending are great but not transcendent, like the whole OST, which is correct but quite redundant every now and then.


     The two central characters have two different personalities and embody two styles of camping: camping alone and camping with friends, respectively applied by Rin and Nadeshiko. Each one has its charms:  for the first one, it's the charm of being alone in the nature, adapted to introspection and to the enjoyment of small things (like Rin enjoying meeting dogs on her road); for the second one, it's more about the sweet feeling of sharing a moment with your friends; each one are conveying tranquility and this is what makes this anime a very good slice of life. Rin will influence Nadeshiko in her style of camping and reciprocally.


     I have enjoyed so much this anime that I'm planning on going camping outdoors some days with a bunch of friends :)

-Spoiler alert (or maybe its not)
Well, this anime was one of many anime that can describe what relax spirit is. You can feel it when you watch the anime, even if you start watching the anime from random episode. Its like, every single episode has different meaning with the other, and on every single episode can give different atmosphere to us. That atmosphere come from art that have cool atmosphere and then supported by great soundtrack and best voice actress.
Its sad knowing that the series only have 12 eps. But, i think its enough for slice of life anime.

Out of 100 Nobles watching...
87 were impressed!
10 wanted some more substance.
3 would like a little more from the animation.
In the wake of shows like Attack on Titan's second season and Devilman: Crybaby the world was blessed during the Winter season with Yuru Camp.
Yuru Camp may just be the most thinly veiled piece of propaganda created by the Japanese Parks and Rec department, but that doesn't mean it wasn't a great show.
The show doesn't have much in the way of a story other than following a bunch of high school girls on their camping escapades. The characterization within that concept is presented well though. We haveRin who is a bit of a lone wolf who slowly learns to enjoy the company of others outdoors, Nadeshiko who is a camping novice who wins over others with her pure aura of Genki, and a myriad cast of characters such as the camping green members of the High School Outdoor Activities Club.\n\n
The characters are fairly shallow but they mingle well. There's some slight amount of cliche with different characters feeling a bit one note personality wise, but it's nothing that took me out of the show.\n\n
The visuals here were quite good with sweeping camera shots of Japan's outdoors that made me very nostalgic of my time in the Saitama prefectures countryside not too long ago. Some of the facial animation was a little lazy albeit cute and there was a minimal amount of CG car. I suppose the budget was mainly focused on selling camping in Japan to us, the viewer. \n\n
The soundtrack here was great. The Op [Shiny Days] has to easily be my favorite since Dragon Maids ED [Ishukan Communication]. The episode tracks are very calming and folksie as well. The whole sets a delight.\n\n
Overall if you want something cute, comfortable, and filled with camping trivia then give this one a shot. Cleanse your palate of all those violent, gory anime.

Some might see another 10 rating, and even that Yuru Camp is in my top 10 anime, and think I'll just be another person that showers unfathomable praise for the show.  I feel like the show really can be made or broken by simply your first impressions with the content and its characters.  If you can't like the characters, the show isn't for you.  If you have no interest in the camping or the scenery, maybe it's not a 10 show for you.  That's not the main thing I want to praise here.  This might be one of my largerreviews, let me know how I did.


Story/Art:

I'm tossing these two together because it follows a similar feature.  Camping.  There are two things that come with camping, it being the feature of the story, which isn't exactly too engaging outside of just "hey we want to camp, where are we going camping" and all the antics that have to do with Slice of Life anime.  The art is the scenery of the campsites, which they do a phenomenal job of, including a special thing in the last episode that mirrors the first episode.  Some might have seen the pictures, some might not have.  Watch out for it, even watch the first ep again when you've finished the last episode of the show just to see what I'm talking about.  The scenery is gorgeous, especially seeing the mountains (I grew up seeing a mountain from view of my house, so I appreciate those views).


Character:

Here we have basically 5 characters, though three are somewhat minor.  The first two are Rin and Nadeshiko.  Rin is an active camper and is seen throughout the show on her own solo adventures, which inspires Nadeshiko to start on some camping.  Nadeshiko is hyper and is often compared to Kirby with her eating habits.  I can actually only remember the name of Aoi past this, to show how minor the other three are, and I'm not going to cheat by looking them up.  I think there's something about the characters each having a different accent that's actually neat to look up if you have an interest in it.


Sound:

This is the main thing I want to cover.  The OST is phenomenal, it really represents each nature of the show quite well, and is topped off with the Opening and the Ending are utilized in each episode.  Think of Nadeshiko each episode.  She starts off hyper every episode, but as night hits and the camp gets quiet, even she calms down and is relaxing in the comfy levels the show is intended... now look at the two songs that surround the show.  Shiny Days is a fast paced opening that really starts up a day feeling good, while Furu biyori is a calm, slow song that really fits with the relaxing aspect of the show.  Which is actually entertaining since that's how an episode starts and ends too, it starts hyper, it shows off the scenery, and then steadily gets you comfy.


So enjoyment?  If you love the idea of camping and seeing forests, rivers, just grasslands and don't mind seeing some cute girls doing the camping for you, watch away.

Before I start this review, I just want to say this: Go watch Yuru Camp. You don't need four paragrafs of text telling you why you need to watch it, just go wath Yuru Camp. And if you are not convinced, then sit back, relax and get ready for my review.  
-------------------------------  
I've never camped in my life. I can maybe count those times when I camped on the grass fields of my sport club (I play korfbal, google it), but that was more two days of training that coincidentally had sleeping in a tent as activity. So I'venever camped in a forrest or something like that, but Yuru Camp made me interesting in camping. Yes, a anime suddenly made me interested in something I've never had interest in. So made did this show me interested in camping? Well, get your backpacks and be ready to say ''Rin-chan!'', this is my review of Yuru Camp.  


Story: 7/10  

This is a very simple story, but that isn't a bad thing which I will get into later. Rin is girl who really loves camping, so she decides to go on a solo camping trip. When arriving at the destination, she notices a pink-haired girl sitting alone, but quickly forgets about her. After preparing the tent and a few hours of book reading she decides to go to the bathroom. She gets jumpscared by the pink haired girl and the pink haired girl follows her to the tent. Apparently the pink haired girl is named Nadeshiko and she went on a biking trip but got tired on the way back home. After a bowl of ramen Nadeshiko gets picked up by her sister and Rin continues her camping. A few days later Nadeshiko joins a Camping club because she loved the time she was camping with Rin. In this Camping club are Aoi and Chiaki. From this point it doesn't become a story but more of events that just happen. Again, very simple story, but that isn't a bad thing. The story is clearly not the foccus point and it does its job fine.  


Art & Sound: 10/10 (I would've given a 11/10, but that isn't possible)  

The backgrounds are beautiful. Full of detail and laid-back colors that look stunning. Some of these backgrounds could hang in Louvre. The beautiful backgrounds get complemented by the music, which is... ooh.. oooooh.. ohhoooohoooh... it is so beautiful! The OP is so happy (even if it reminds me of I Want You Back by the Jackson Five), the ED is so relaxing and everything else in between is comfy, relaxing and happy.  


Enjoyment: 10/10  

This anime is the most relaxing anime I have ever seen. The sound and the backgrounds combined with excellent pacing makes for a anime that is just a joy from beginning to end. Every episode was comfy. Every episode gave me a chuckle (oh yeah, this anime has comedy). Every episode was perfect.  


Overall: 10/10

Watch it.

I love the Japanese landscape in real life. So a show featuring it is a must-see for me by this merit alone.
This anime is far exceeding my and perhaps anybody's expectation. Perhaps the first hint of it being a hit was the VA's list: Touyama Nao, one of the three "magicians" VAs highly praised by the Chinese (the other two are Taneda Risa and Sakura Ayane). Toyosaki Aki, the Yui in K-On! and a member of Sphere. Apart from them, nothing else was really eye-catching at first glance.
But the opening with Rin riding her bike along the road towards Motosuko in Autumn Japan was alreadya treat. Japan is really that beautiful - an industrial country still spotted with pristine landscape. And the show knows it and capitalizes on it. It alternates camping site for camping site in the late Japanese autumn. It was a good change since most audience were quite exposed to the Sakura Japanese Spring by many other animes (Shigatsu wa kimi no uso, Hyouka and on and on). Red sugar maple trees with other golden trees lined up the shores of Shibireko in ep 6 & 7 were breathtaking. 


One of the best episodes, the Chinese and Japanese crown it with "神回" (godlike episode), is ep. 5. The outside Hottokeya onsen with a view over Yamanashi city was a killer. 40°C water, the best weather, under the most relaxing music, the girls just were submerging themselves in all these- Nadeshiko summed it up "極楽、極楽" (heavenly comfort, heavenly comfort). On the parallel side, Rin's repeating "温泉！温泉！温泉！" just makes the whole thing more comforting.


Then it comes to camping and finally the sweet night photo scene - Nadeshiko sent Rin a photo of Yamanashi while Rin sent Nadeshiko a shot of the picturesque Suwa lake, all under orginal music with the title "高ボッチ、イーストウッド" (the names of two camping sites). Especially when Rin took her shot, the uplifting background music with a female voice chanting in it was just pure gold. 


This is an anime, where the joy for camping, the awe in front of the night scenery and the quiet environment are all there. But it is also an anime about friendship among our 5 heroines. They were happy camping because they had each other. Even in ep. 1 which looked like a Rin's solo, it was only heating up after Nadeshiko's joining. And ever since then, the fun of camping had never been the same: culminating in episodes 3, 5, 7 and the last two, all with Nadeshiko.


The pacing of the anime was also special. It followed a A-B-A-B-A rhythm, where a camping episode was followed by an intermission (traveling, planning and shopping) so that we didn't get too much a camping overdose and didn't soon lose our appetite. Without a question, the camping episodes were the highlights, but we would have enjoyed them slightly less if it those filler episodes weren't there.


Also the educational aspect of the show is refreshing. Ootsuka Akio voiced the narrative insert with quite a humor sense.


The music OP+ED+OST is perhaps one of the most anticipated of the season. The OP is high-spirited song that kicked open most of the episodes. While the OST and the EP are just max comfying. The OST, played with whistles, string instruments and guitars, is just delivering everything we need for the show and then some.


I believe that many viewers around the world, me included have thoroughly enjoyed this show so very much. It will be perhaps some years away for a season 2. But let's just wait. And in the meantime, go to Japan to see the landscape ourselves!

There's nothing significant with the story, but there's character development there. But you shouldn't really focus on the story. 7
Art is explainable. 10
The sound is on par with the anime's theme. 10

Overall, it should score a 9, but I just gave it a 10 because this is a masterpiece that we don't see much often.

This is my first time writing a review in MAL. Since I really enjoyed Yuru Camp, might as well tell you why I gave it an overall 9. 
Art - 10
Ah, yes. Clearly seen from the first throughout the last episode, the atmospheric background and complimentary colours feel so natural and appealing to the eyes. There is no dull moment, everything is full in colour yet pleasing. It also allows you to feel the vibe of warmth or coldness as if you were part of the scene. 
There is also good colour harmony with character designs like how Rin and Nadeshiko compliment colours (see theireyes and hair colour) or the characters' outfit. Also liked how they chose pastel colours for this.


Character - 10

At first glance, the art style seemed cutesy and well having watched 300+ anime, my first impression was the cliché fan service and typical personality types but there was none which I really liked. I like my slice of life with a sense of realism and relives the mind when watching. The characters can be grouped between calm and hyper but all unique in their ways. For example, Saitou and Rin are both calm but Rin is more active. 


The show also made good use of when to use supporting characters or when they should enter. Supporting characters are usually portrayed as props but here they are memorable and likeable. 


Sound - 10

Enjoyment - 9


Story - 9

The setting & plot is already unique for me, camping... in winter. Setting: outside of the norms like not at home, no beach.. or festivals which most of us already know what event takes place. Yuru Camp shows you a different place or experience. One selling point of this is the mysteriousness of what the next campsite would be.


I think it thought well of its audience.. relativity. What I studied in Media class is that most people like to relate. (I try my best to be spoiler free so..) The show sometimes add scenarios which the audience had experience like malfunctions of equipment and audience wanting to camp would be like 'oh yeah.. this could happen.. oh no.' then they leave tips on how to avoid it just to leave satisfaction and stop the uneasiness. 


Overall - 9


Its a thoughtfully well-crafted work. I, evidently, gave it a high praise.

However, I find myself watching it and stopping halfway. Maybe just self-preference but I truly did enjoy. Hoping to see more from Kyougoku, Yoshiaki! Its his debut anime but did an awesome job.

There are some days when you just don't feel like doing anything. You want to lie down, roll in your bed, have a cup of coffee near you and binge something that doesn't make you work up that much. Yuru Camp is just that kind of anime.
There's not much stories, no sudden plots and jumps, no romance(thankfully) and no excessive emotional stuff. It's just like the river which flows on and on, peacefully, without disturbing anybody. Yuru Camp is just like that. Sit back and get prepared for a comfy ride.
The art is soothing. Not great, not bad, just plain, simple soothing. The one thatmakes you feel happy and warm.


Sound is topnotch. The background music is just perfect and it does an excellent job portraying the calm mother nature. As for the OP, it is a bit catchy and has a nice vibe to it. The real gem is the ED, probably the best this season. So peaceful and calm. I loved it!


Yuru Camp deals with your average cute high school girls going on camping trips. Don't expect to find some huge character developments. Just watch the girls enjoy. It feels damn real. Nadeshiko, as the bubbly cheerful girl, instantly makes everyone love her. Rin, on the other hand, gives off a solemn vibe at the beginning, but it slowly dissapears, and you get to see her friendly and cheerful self. The other girls are also great. Cheerful, happy and each with their own brand of self.


Overall, I'd ask everyone to watch Yuru Camp. It's the perfect definiton for Iyashikei, something which heals your soul. Sit back, leave your critical thoughts aside, and enjoy watching a group of normal girls enjoying camping. I swear that after watching a few episodes you'd want to pack up, and go camping too. At least I know I am going to a trip soon with my friends.


TL;DR: Yuru Camp is one of the best shows this season. It heals, it pleases and it wants to make you go camping. If you loved Flying Witch, be sure to watch this. If you didn't, watch this still. I promise that Yuru Camp won't dissapoint.

TL;DR – A comfy show with fun and lovable characters that I can pick up and watch no matter what mood I'm in. 
Basic breakdown below ⬎
== Impressions / Presentation: 8/10 ==
Yuru Camp does a great job relating its outdoor camping premise to the audience. The show accurately captures the fun emotions involved with the process, from the preparation all the way to the camping itself. Even those unfamiliar with outdoor camping will be charmed by how joyfully the anime presents the idea.
C-Station has opted to use soundtrack inspired by traditional Celtic / Irish music, which fits the primarily outdoor setting. The pretty visuals aresimple but detailed enough in areas that matter. Both synergise well to give the show a very pleasant and comfy atmosphere.




== "Story": 7/10 ==


The theme of the show can basically be summed up as: showcasing the joys of outdoor camping (with friends). I have already mentioned it does a great job of this, and I have no complaints in this regard.


As for what literally happens in any given episode, seeing what the characters get up to is always fun, and I always look forward to their future shenanigans.


Despite the crux of the show revolving around watching them have a great time, it always feels like the show is progressing towards a goal of some kind. This gives it that sense of direction that I find a lot of Slice of Life shows lack, which in turn gives birth to that feeling of pointlessness you sometimes get.




== Characters: 7.5/10 ==


Characters are cute in both design and personality. Going about everything with lots of energy + great chemistry on top of that makes them very fun to watch.


Normally in SoL / CGDCT shows, there's a standout character that I enjoy watching more than the rest. But in Yuru Camp, I can honestly say I love watching them all.




== Enjoyment: 8/10 ==


Enjoyment from Yuru Camp comes in the form of warm fuzzy feelings, wearing a goofy grin on your face, and occasionally dying from the comedy. Needless to say, it's a lot of fun.




If all this sounds like your cup of hot cocoa, give this a watch already!

Probably LA's most relaxing and "comfiest" anime of Winter 2018 and LA loved it!
Yuru Camp△ is an all girls cast slice of life anime about camping and even though LA is a rather "indoor" type rather than an outdoor type like the majority of the cast, LA doesn't need to say that this kind of slice of life anime won't get LA to camp any time soon, but nonetheless it's definitely one of those animes that you don't need TOO much investment in and you can just relax just like the cast and see them eat delicious food in the process.
Yuru Camp△ DOES have astory as much as it's usually about our main cast just camping in different spots of actual real life Japanese locations. One of the focal points of this anime is Rin Shima voiced by Nao Touyama, a loner-type camper who gradually opens up to group camping later on thanks to newcomer Nadeshiko Kagamikara, a rather eccentric bottomless stomach character who joins the Outdoor Club with their two founding members Aoi Inuyama voiced by Aki Tyosaki and Chiaki Oogaki voiced by Sayuri Hara. The other more informative parts of Yuru Camp△ is talking about camping equipment to how much of an actual expensive or cheap hobby camping is with the narrator voiced by Akio Ootsuka.


So by in large we see the majorty of the screentime with Nadeshiko and Rin, what with Rin's solo camping and by that end Rin was LA's favourite character, both in terms of her tsukommi routine with Nadeshiko, personality (as LA is similar) aaaaaaaaand...Nao Touyama (you know LA was gonna say it). Nadeshiko is a good character as well what with her allowing Rin to open herself up to the Outdoor Club and being the boke to Rin's tsukommi and soon doing duo camping with Rin to group camping by the end of it. Aoi and Chiaki have extremely good chemistry with each other, both character and voice acting wise as they too have a boke to tsukommi routine (Chiaki boke to Aoi's tsukommi) and their interactions with the rest of the cast is fun and interesting as well. We do have a fifth and sixth ranger to the cast which are Rin's friend Ena Saitou voiced by Rie Takahashi who teases her at times (for comedy of course) and also tries to open Rin up to the Outdoor club AND Minami Toba voiced by Shizuka Ito, who becomes the Outdoor Club's advisor and one hell of lovable drunk.


As much as Yuru Camp△ sounds like a lull and uninteresting of an anime to get through, LA by all accounts had ALOT of fun relaxing with the cast and what their next camping expedition is and for a slice of life, it did it's job well, both being informative about it's main focus of camping as well as having a great and interesting cast (coupled with some of comedic moments that landed ALOT) and all having a atmospherically intentionally relaxing tone to it just made this anime a breeze to get through with NO sign of boredom for LA.


So if there were any flaws Yuru Camp△ has then it's on how Yuru Camp△ goes on highs then lows, by that LA means the highs being the episodes where the characters are actually camping and the lows being when the characters are NOT camping and more or less prepping for equipment or locations for their next camping place, to Yuru Camp△'s defense, LA WILL say in those lows we do get to see the characters interact with someone different (at times) or just get to know them personality-wise outside of camping and that can help getting to like the cast better.


Yuru Camp△ does have some minor revelations mostly concerning family members reveal but for this kind of anime, you can either take it like you will or ignore it but nonetheless Yuru Camp△ does have some details to it that you can keep an eye out for or again...just go with the flow of the episode.


In terms of animation by C-Station, well for a slice of life anime centred around camping, the backgrounding work was gorgeous to say the least what with real life locations animated beautifully AND deliciously animated food to the point you'd ALSO want to eat something at the same time and even though the animation tends to go chibi or the like, it is used for comedic effect and it works like it should. The character designs are unique enough with some "like mother, like daughter" scenarios here and there but that's expected as well. If C-Station's merits are anywhere it's in the backgrounding and it's comedic timing animation.


Now voice acting...well if you know LA, you'd know that Nao Touyama would be MVP and your right but in all seriousness for this kind of anime, LA really enjoyed the ENTIRE voice cast, from Aki Toyosaki's tsukommi moments with Sayuri Hara's genki eccentricties to Nao Touyama doing a her kuudere cadence and Yumiri Hanamori once again doing her genki schtick as well as Rie Takahashi's typical vocals all of whom doing it WELL and finally Shizuka Ito's drunkenness meta-joked cadence as Minami Toba. LA LOVED this voice cast, what else is there to say?


Well if you haven't already guessed it but LA will say what LA said at the start of this review, "Probably LA's most relaxing and "comfiest" anime of Winter 2018 and LA loved it!", well it shows by the end of this. LA didn't expect to enjoy Yuru Camp△ as much as LA thought but it did was better than LA expected. Though the Winter 2018 was packed with ALOT of contenders for best anime of the season, LA would at least give Yuru Camp△ LA's best slice of life anime for the Winter of 2018 if at that for being a relaxing anime without being boring, excellently done characters with great chemistry with one another along with good comedic routines that doens't get stale and focusing on the slice of life hobby of camping all wrapped into one.

I would like to preface this by saying: You cannot copy the fire-starting techniques used in this show if you live anywhere in the Western U.S.  Brush fires are a real thing, and some of these "techniques" are dangerous to copy with dry brush around. That being said, if anyone is motivated to camp by this show that is an absolutely wonderful thing. You should find no shame in it, hell, I bought my own tent because of this show.
This was actually the first CGDCT I started watching. While I finished Girls und Panzer before the end of this series, I actually only startedit because Yuru Camp along with Slow Start made me realize I was avoiding it for the wrong reasons. Now, Yuru Camp didn't necessarily blow me out of the water, but it did have a few things going for it:


1. The food presentation was amazing. You could have told me this was a camping cooking show for the first six episodes and I might have believed you. The preparation of the food is toned down by the second half, yet it still plays a big part. I had to be drinking tea or water whenever I watched this, or I got cravings for every little thing.


2. The show is cute.


3. The character interaction is decent. No one really changes over the course of the "journey" except one character, however it at least sets out its goal from the start.


Overall, I'd say this delivers on good food animations, cute cast, decent location panoramas, and it sets its atmosphere very well. If that's all you're really looking to get out of a show, then this isn't a bad place to start.

Ahh, Yuru Camp. One of the most relaxing anime I have ever watched. Don't let the hype around it confuse you. Watching the anime is like drinking alcohol to forget your problems. It really made my week everytime I watched it.
First of all, let me talk about the story. This is obviously where this anime is weak because there's not really much going on besides girls going out camping. At least it's not another generic high school slice of life anime because the anime barely had any story about the school the main characters attend to. This can be either good or bad depending onthe viewer but a change in location is good every once in a while. The story isn't really that bad but I would place it between 4-5 since the story wasn't good enough to be called mediocre while it also feels unfair to give it a 4 (Fair). Since MyAnimeList doesn't allow decimals in reviews, I would still consider it a 5 since I think that the story is actually closer to mediocre than fair. The story isn't really memorable in this anime so if you're looking for an anime with a really good story that will blow your mind, this anime isn't the one you are looking for.


Next is the artwork. Boy, this anime had one of the most stunning screencaps I have ever seen. Mount Fuji looks so beautiful in this anime and against the real Mount Fuji, I'd even say that there were moments in the anime where the scenery looked better and more realistic than in real life. Regarding the artwork on characters, I have no complaints. I'd even throw lots of compliments to C-Station for nailing the cuteness of the characters. They got Nadeshiko's faces to work without looking like garbage while also maintaining her cuteness. Although the artwork carried this anime's score, it was also one of the causes for me not considering this anime as a masterpiece. While the animation was mostly good, there were times that the bad qualities of the animation were obvious to the viewer's vision. I'm not sure if this counts as a spoiler but the animation in episode 8 was clearly one of the worst in the entire show. I tried reading more about this and found out that another studio handled the animation on this episode. While some may give it consideration, it still hurts the score for me since I'm rating the overall anime here. While most errors in animation were minor, it's still a fact that this anime has lots of amazing screencaps and potential wallpapers or maybe even some profile pictures for your social media needs. And because of that, I'm sure with myself that this anime's art deserves a score of 9/10 for all the amazing eye candy that it showed.


The sound was also one of the reasons why I love this anime so much. First of all, you have lots of amazing music to choose from the soundtrack if you want a music session. The two songs that I liked the best were the OP and the ED. Personally, this is the 2nd anime where I don't skip the OP and ED while watching (New Game S1 being the first).『SHINY DAYS』and 『ふゆびより』were so amazing and so catchy that I couldn't stop listening to the both of them. Of course, the soundtrack in the anime which feels old-timey was also fitting for the theme of camping because the music makes you feel like you are also camping even if you're just watching at home. The only complaint that I have regarding the sound is that while watching the anime, Most of the music would just be repeated again which is fine but they overused some background music and that just made some scenes mediocre. I pick a rating based on the description of the number and judging what each of the numbers says, I picked 8 since "Very Good" is what comes into mind when I first thought about the soundtrack of the anime.


Regarding the characters, the two main characters (Rin & Nadeshiko) were pretty much the only characters that feel unique. Rin is there so she can be herself (Lonely camper) with her camping equipment while I can almost classify Nadeshiko as average but her obsession with Mount Fuji saved her character. The other characters feel like they don't even need to be in the show. I'm not talking about the characters that the girls meet along the way but I'm talking about the secondary characters such as Chiaki, Aoi, and Saitou. First, regarding Chiaki, her character doesn't really fit in the show for some reason. Aoi had her "Seyana" but it wasn't enough to prevent her from being generic while Saitou's presence was mostly just in texts. These three characters had the potential to become better but I guess you can't really fit that much character development in 12 episodes so I won't judge the creators or having mediocre characters. For the score, I would of have given this portion of the rating 8 if all the characters were like Nadeshiko and Shimarin in terms of having a good character but since they were mediocre, I gave a rating of 6/10.


The enjoyment is pretty much self-explanatory. This is one of the most relaxing anime I have ever watched and I'm not ashamed of giving this portion of the rating a 10/10 because watching this anime pretty much removed a week's worth of stress. For those who are still reading this review up to this part, congratulations. I will tell you the best way of enjoying this anime. First of all, DON'T BINGE. Watch the episodes in intervals of 1 week as if it's in broadcast because this anime isn't that enjoyable if you binge it all in one sitting.


To conclude all of these, The weak points of this anime were the story and character but it was countered by beautiful art, an amazing soundtrack, and the overall comfiness of this anime. If you are planning on watching this anime, please use the method that I wrote in the enjoyment section because that really is the best method of watching this anime (At least for me). This anime made me (shut-in) want to go outside and camp. That's something that this show should be proud of since it isn't easy making a shut-in leave the house.

This could be regarded as the camping equivalent to Takunomi, but instead of trying to get everyone completely blotto on the drink-of-the-week, this gets people exciting about camping, both as a solo activity and as a group one.  As an advertisement for said activity and all the required equipment, it does an exceedingly good job.
There is one series-long story (of which you see the result of in the first episode), and whilst most episodes are individually linked, you do see the main story being built up over all the episodes.
The characters themselves are very nice with individual characteristics, who all compliment each other verywell, and are very well designed and animated.


Occasionally a narrator fills in various details, which makes things more real.


All other graphics are pretty nicely detailed too, with a nice use of 3D when needed.  


The title music is great, but the end credit tune isn't as good.


You may feel that it is a bit slow, but it is worth watching for the entirety if only to look at the scenery

super relaxing , simple and beautiful. it gives a great enjoyment with its simple art and beautiful background music . loved ending theme song. the relaxation from this is legendary. didn't thought that SOL in 2018 will be this much good. no flashy scenes, no hardcore actions, just simple and slow . if u need some relax, this is best pick. 
character designs are good with their cuteness. and how excitement of characters on camping shows our excitement on camping. art is simple and smooth.  
sound is godlike and vocals in ending theme just heals u with their voice
story relates to everyone who lovescamping and outside adventures. even though you are not in camping, u will be overjoyed by this masterpiece. \n
most relaxing anime for me . if u feeling brooken just watch this u will be healed by its glory

This is hands down my favorite anime this season.  It's got it all....Great characters.  Cuteness, but not too much cuteness.  Beautiful scenery.  Yummy food.  
Don't care for camping?  This may make you want to go.  One girl goes by herself to get away.  She puts up her tent, cooks her noodles and enjoys the night sky over Mt. Fuji.  Another girl show up, lost, and ends up sharing her fire and soon her love of camping.  Enter the camping club at their local high school and the story gets bigger with more character development (andsome helpful camping advice for the viewer.)\n\n
This anime makes me wish I had camped more when I lived near Fuji-san.

In an action packed season with blood spilled and wars, Yuru Camp is there to remedy it all.
Story 8: I don't think the story will improve at the end of the series. However the story itself isn't bad at all. it is relaxing without any dramas, conflicts, etc and that is what i want from this show and it delivers it well. So no complaint, a solid 8 from me.
Art 9: the scenery is so good. The foods also look delicious. The character design is also spot on. They all are cute to be expected from an anime about cute girl doing cute thing. Moreimportantly that the art's quality is consistent every episode.


Sound 10: A relaxing soundtrack one of the strong point of this anime I think. The music and the scene perfectly fit together. The ED is amazing one of the best for me this season. I really loving it.


Character 7: All girls have their own personalities, that's all. Sadly they are not memorable enough for me. They are kinda generic. Rin is loner which open up a bit as the series progress, Nadeshiko is a noisy, carefree which easy to befriend anyone. And the others, I even couldn't remember their name.


Overall (8 + 9 + 10 + 7 + 10 = 44 / 5 = 8.8) : An easy to pick series. A good show to acompany you while you are eating or just want to relax. Just about girls go camp with a slight education about how to do it right. 

If you are tired of actions, blood, conflicts, or dramas pick this series to remedy those. 


I love the simple story, the great OST, a delicious looking foods, a beautiful scenery.

Although the characters are kinda generic, they still do their job well enough to not hinder the other aspects of this series.


Let's go camping, contact me if you have any plan to go camping, I might join you! ( l o l )..

Well, to begin with i have to say this: this is not a complex story, or something to make you think, this anime is something to make you relax and be distracted. So if you came here looking for some good storytelling or character development, you came to the wrong place.
  This show is basically a moe slice of life a.k.a "cute girls doing cute things", this genre is basically oversaturated, but this show brings something new to the table, it has a good premise, and it is done well.
  So, the story is about a group of girls,who gather around in a school club, and go camping together. Well, that's it. the story isn't the most complex, but it works for this type of anime.


  The art and the sound, are done very well, you have beautiful landscapes and good sounds around the camping parts, good enough to make you want to camp too.


  The characters are pretty basic, they have their personality, which is quite remarkable in each character. The motivations are basically: they want to camp. Well, i didnt expected nothing more than that anyways. 


  I enjoyed a lot the series, i've never felt so relaxed with an anime in my entire life, and in some episodes i was in awe by the beautiful scenery.


 Overall, i recommend to everyone who wants a good and relaxing experience with an anime. And i will make sure to watch if they ever releases a new season.

Yuru Camp - A show where comfiness can embark someone's heart to forget problems and such.
I did not know what to expect about a camping Anime and it was not that special in my expectations back in Winter 2018. In fact, it was a show I would just watch since I just wanted to watch more but it surpassed my expectation and saw how amazing this show is. This show made me love CGDCT(Cute Girls Doing Cute Things) Anime much more and it made me look for shows as outstanding as this.
Yuru Camp's story is just simple and it was easy to follow through. Friendshipsbetween the camp-mates, adventuring in a campsite, sitting by a campfire, having the ideal camping gear, sleeping in a tent, having stories and so many more, Yuru Camp made these simple camping activities into an experience in which it is memorable and enjoyable. The show does not try so hard to hit audiences with an overwhelming storyline but it made a simple show about camping with friends a calming show to watch.


The art is great with the characters having special features to each of them and the amazing background or sceneries which gives a realistic feel. The sceneries in Yuru Camp gives off a relaxing vibe by just looking at it.


The sound is one of the features of this show, especially the OST. It is one of my favorite OSTs that I have ever heard. The soundtrack of Yuru Camp really fits the scenes and it makes it memorable. It also gives off a cozy and jolly feeling which enhances the watching experience. The OP and ED songs are also great especially the opening which is catchy.


The characters of Yuru have different personalities that suits each other and with their amazing VAs gives off a nice chemistry. Shimarin and Nadeshiko are the most memorable characters for me. Their friendship started off with just camping and shows that friendship can grow from interests. The Aoi, Chiaki and Ena are also great with their chemistry it makes the show relatable and it is enjoyable to watch their random conversations which are simple but fun.


I enjoyed Yuru Camp really well and it is my favorite show last 2018. Having to watch this show every week after school, usually end of the weekdays is one of the greatest things that happened to me last year. It helped me reduce my stress and anxiety which was kicking off since it was very busy and I found myself at a hard situation last year. With the comfy, calm, relaxing and cozy feeling this show gives off, it can make me forget my problems to bounce back and resolve it. I could have not asked for a show to be this amazing coincide with the hard times.


Thus, this show is a masterpiece with a simple but memorable story, an outstanding art which gives a great viewing experience, the best and comfy soundtracks that runs fluidly with scenes, the fun characters and a stress reliever makes this Anime one of a kind.

This anime goes into the genre of "cute girls doing cute things" however as soon as you finish the first episode you see that there is more to that.
In fact the animation, the osts, and the ending does such a good job making you blend into the peaceful atmosphere of the show.
I watched this during my exams period and it really helped me relax between two long hours of studying.
The best thing i can say about this show is that it made an otaku introvert who dislike sun and human interaction and who prefer the darkness of her room, want to go camping.
Seriously i wantto go camping lol.\n\n
I recommend it to slice of life lovers but also to people who are looking for a peaceful yet not boring and funny show.

Yuru Camp is an anime about people finding comfort in camping, a niche hobby; that just happened to have cute characters in it. While the main setup is simple, the point of the show is to express the grandeur that is to be found in simple pleasures.
The main cast members are all in love with camping in the great outdoors. it isn't exactly a cheap nor popular hobby. To them the experience is worth the hassle.
And this is what the show exists to do. It frames their relationships as comforting, their desperate efforts to collect money to fund their hobby as something worth admiringand the final outcome of their efforts, the time they spend on their trip, as an experience worthy of envy. This is supported by the visuals. Most interpersonal moments are portrayed in a super deformed style to convey intimacy and a sense of comfort. Meanwhile the hard work, the effort required for such a hobby is shown in a relatively realistic style so that the viewers associate it with reality. This is backed by a soundtrack that is reminisce of folk tunes, to usher in memories of the great outdoors.\n\n
The show is technically impressive and showcases just what can be done in a standard TV budget if the creators pour in enough passion. But the main draw to Yuru Camp is the emotions it inspires in it's viewers and not the sum of it's parts.\n\n
Watch it, especially if you need something akin to a pick me up, so that you can feel just a bit better.

Reviewing Yuru Camp with a numeric value is a difficult task, because while it accomplishes everything that it attempts quite beautifully, it admittedly doesn't attempt much. This begs the question, should something be praised for not trying to be more than it needs to be? Or should ambition be commended, even in projects that miss the mark?
Despite the fact that it is a breath of fresh air amongst countless projects that try to be all things for all people, only to end up being poor in every regard, Yuru Camp happily sets its own ceiling not too far from above average, and that is whereit must be met. This is an anime that ventures to be nothing more than cute, comfy, and cozy and successfully epitomises all three.


(I must also make the disclaimer that I don't care much about food, and food gets more screen-time in this anime than most characters)


Yuru Camp shines when the Outdoor Activities Club members' antics are on display, with Chiaki, Aoi, and Nadeshiko bouncing off each other hilariously.  This is balanced well with 'Shimarin' bringing a more relaxed atmosphere with her solo camping endeavours that present us with some beautiful visuals, occasionally mixed with genuinely informative narration on camping. Without much of a story to speak of, the only real motivation to watch Yuru Camp is to decompress. This is why its slow pacing and repetition are non-issues - it really is about the journey because there is no destination. The characters themselves are nothing exceptional, but are unique enough to be likeable in their own ways and some show a decent amount of growth considering the lack of story or conflict as the episodes go on.


It is also worth mentioning that as the season nears its end, it shows the potential for more entertainment in the future as all the characters interact with each other more frequently. While I can understand if other viewers prefer the chilled solo camping or food montages that consume a fair amount of time per episode, I do believe the comedic group atmosphere is a strength that could be doubled down on successfully in the upcoming sequel and movie.


The music in Yuru Camp stands out among its peers. The catchy background ditties remind me of playing Animal Crossing growing up, and always work to enhance the tone of the foreground. The opening theme, Shiny Days, is nothing short of a mf banger, making it one of very few openings I refuse to skip.


Overall, Yuru Camp is the perfect example of a "healing" anime - something to shut your brain off to, or calm your anxiety. It is not, however, a particularly memorable watch, and that's okay. Yuru Camp is almost situational: like a cold beer after a long day, you'll know when you need it, and when you do there's nothing out there that could replace it.

It often seems that, once an established trend forms in anime, it gets increasingly hard to remove the trend from the possible story pool. Mecha, the post- or slightly pre-World War II or similar setting, and the “transported to another world” genre as of late constitute a few different examples. During the last half to full decade the obsession with cute girls doing cute things firmly established itself, whether that be daily life, playing in a band, or piloting tanks. 
     Yuru Camp is very much a cute girls doing cute things show, with itsunique distinguishing feature being a focus and even informative take on camping in the colder months of the year. With its unique selling point firmly established, Yuru Camp doesn’t so much dive into cute girls doing cute things as gently sidle up, wrapped in a warm blanket and carry cup noodles.\n
	The animation can be split into two specific compartments of the actual art and the animation of the moving parts. The art is wonderful. The character art lacks extreme detail, but incorporates the same soft and comfy ideals the rest of the show revolves around. Many of the landscape shots appear slightly fuzzy, but still recognizable in their subject matter, and have a great personalized unique unique to Yuru Camp as a whole. \n
      The backgrounds often consist of landscapes and other open areas where such things as individual trees and blades of grass are not important, but their representation gives a flair to the rest of the show due to the amount of care and stylization put into backgrounds. Buildings, structures, and other man made objects are still done in a softer, subdued color palate, but stand out from the natural backgrounds as much more detailed. The contrast blends well and helps distinguish different parts of each frame from one another and for their respective uses.\n
	Actual animation is very average and contains minimal detailing. The difference and flatness of the cast and other moving objects causes them to be clearing distinguished from the background, but feel out of place against then more stylized backgrounds. The animation is by no means a detractor to the show as a whole, but certainly does not offer an improvements. Detailed and precise animation, while potentially the icing on the cake of an action series, is not particularly important for one like this where the fasts movement is the chop of wood or the eating of good, warm food.\n
	Music often fills little purpose beyond filling in the background silence, but Yuru Camp absolutely excels in standing out from anime of any genre. The instrument choice in itself is unique, full of plucking string instruments and gentle strumming. The whistle and harmonica accompaniment really brings forth ideas of mountains, quiet streams, and bright days spent outdoors under the sun. The tone of the music also pairs nicely with the laid back nature of the show, setting the mood for weekends and holidays from work and school spent preparing for trips and setting off into the great outdoors. \n
	The characters and their actions create the central draw of the show. Each character has an incredibly distinct personality that, while perhaps predictable based on appearance, interacts well with the other characters. Some are more accident prone than others, some are more experienced, and some have the capabilities to take care of, and teach from, the different experience newer campers face. The result is a situation of constant characters growth as each of the main cast is put in new situations that are not their strong suit and must learn to work with the others to have successful camping outings. Bringing all the characters together comes back to the central premise of cute girls doing cute things during their teenage years. \n
	The main plot is fairly simple, building each episode upon the events of the last, yet each even being mostly contained in a single episode. Characters learn about camping, proper methods for the campsites, and how to deal with problems that arise during their trips. There is also a fair amount of information provided on real world proper methods, inviting the viewers to learn along with the cast and gain a greater appreciation for camping as a hobby. Events and experiences learned in earlier episodes are then exemplified and continued in later ones to reinforce the expanding knowledge of the main cast. The growth and increased capabilities of each character reinforces that passing of time and the growth of the character themselves.\n

The „cute girls doing cute things” genre has a lot of supporters, yet people who find it boring are also present. Their main accusation is that these anime are too similar and many of them lack originality. Yuru Camp, however,  takes us off the beaten track … literally. 
  What really distinguishes Yuru Camp from other adorable slice of life anime is the fact that the main interest of the series is placed on, as you can figure from the title, camping. Instead of already explored concepts, this show takes us to a new outdoor scenery. Characters will be spending timein the mountains, near lakes or in the woods and performing activities like putting up the tent, collecting wood or cooking on a campfire.  Besides actually doing something, we will also have enough time to easefully enjoy landscapes, which are truly gorgeous. Yuru Camp offers miscellaneous views, ranging from solitude mountainous regions to towns illuminating among the darkness of the night. All of them have high-quality graphics and vivid, lively colours. This harmonizes well with the cosy BGM, somewhat similar to the Scandinavian folk music. In fact, before I knew about this anime I had first come across its soundtrack on Youtube and honestly, this was the reason I started to watch it. Beautiful animation and well fitted music create a calming atmosphere of leisure. This kind of “feel good” vibe is reminding me of other show: “Non Non Biyori”, so if you liked one of these anime, it might be worth checking out the other.   


  During our journey into the wild outdoors, we will be accompanied by a bunch of likeable characters. Among them, Shima Rin can be considered the main one. She is a bit reserved girl and an introvert who prefers to camp alone. Her personality is being confronted with sociable and lively Nadeshiko. This duo works well, as these two act a bit like a counterweight to each other. Over the show, we will see how their chemistry evolves, as Rin starts to accept a vigorous nature of her friend, which is breaking her solitude and eventually making her more sociable. Nadeshiko herself is a cute and a bit clumsy girl with tones of positive energy that she constantly transfers to the viewer.  This character works as the main drive force for the comedy in the show, which is on a decent level.  From simple puns to situational gags, we are offered with an intelligent and original humour (free of sexual jokes); most of which is derived from character’s distinguished personalities and their mutual relations.


  Even though I am speaking highly of this show, to be fully honest I need to mention some of its drawbacks. I have already described how well this anime does when it shows characters on camping. However, there are also some episodes in between “camping sessions”, in which Nadeshiko and her friends are at school or work, earning money to go on a next trip. While it does add some realism to the story, in my opinion, it could have been omitted, so that we would spend more time camping in the wild, which is, after all, the main theme of this show. Another flaw of “Yuru camp” is the marginalization of some characters. Rin and Nadeshiko are both well designed and we spend a lot of time with them, however other characters are a bit on a sideline. We do not have a chance to explore their personalities and mutual chemistry; they appear rather episodically, which is especially a waste in terms of Inuyama Aoi, a character voiced by Aki Toyosaki, an extremely talented seiyuu (she also voiced Yui Hirasawa from K-on!).  Sadly, in this show, she is not able to show her full potential, as not much focus is placed on Aoi. 


  If you like slice of life, “feel good” anime, then Yuru Camp would probably suit your taste. It is a neatly crafted show, both in terms of audiovisuals and the characters. While having minor drawbacks, it is definitely able to distinguish itself among alike anime and will probably be a part and parcel of every annual top anime list in 2018.

Life is hard. Life has a structure, wake up, eat breakfast, go to work or school, eat dinner and sleep, rinse and repeat. It is repetitive, endless and hard. In this hustle and bustle of life, we forget most simple things, things that shape us, things that we want, the thing’s that we desire and work toward, that thing is beauty and change. A warm summer breeze touching the skin gently as a mother, A cold winter wind refreshing our senses and sending a shiver down the spine, a cool shower of rain on the face refreshing us and nature with rejuvenating power after hotand long summer(For Indians), the half moon hidden behind the clouds like a shy child, setting sun painting the sky with his setting glory creating the most beautiful painting or simply a look at the vast endless blue sky to remind us how tiny we and our problems are.\n\n
Daily life can become stale and boring when did we last looked up to the sky to marvel at its vastness when did we last marvelled at the colours of the dying sun, when did we last felt the cool light of moon calming our skin, probably a long time ago and most probably we don’t even remember. Yuru Camp is anime about camping. It revolves around the basic of the basic desires of a human being. The desire to seek change, a desire for seeking inspiration and meaning in the life. This desire drives us to grow but we lose our roots, what better ‘change’ than to see sun paint the sky each day with the different colours and clouds taking different shapes and position to make the characters and objects on the largest painting ever painted on the largest canvas. What better inspiration than nature which constantly changes and shapes our surroundings. Of course Yuru camp is not that complicated but it is based on that desire and I will leave you with a recommendation to try it out.

This anime is definitely a must-watch of the season, a simple anime with a huge impact.
Story: 8
Yuru Camp has a simple story that portrays a bunch of girls having a passion of outdoor camping and as they embark on the various trips, the story paces itself well and allows time for the narration and this way, not only can we admire the beauty of outdoor camping this anime displays, we are able to learn something new every episode.
Art: 9
Having moe blob designs can potentially ruin an initially good anime if not carefully utilized. However, this simple yet cute character designs really complements the direction ofthe show, with it being an enjoyable "slice of life" anime. As they enjoy their camping trip, together with its character design, the depiction of the campfire and the nighttime ambiance, it really managed to make the audience feel warm and fuzzy inside, making us feel as if we are right beside them enjoying the scenery. Also, the scenery is realistic, yet once again beautifully depicted and really captures the beauty of each and every one of the must-see destination spots in Japan.\n\n
Sound: 10\n
The OST is easily one of, if not the very best of the season. The tune being unconventional and new, yet perfectly setting a calm scene where the characters are free of the stress we are exposed to in reality. In this anime, the times they spend are always adventurous and fun, and the OST of the show brings you into the scenes at the right moments.\n\n
Character: 7 \n
Even though the characters are not the highlight of the show, the characters are brilliant in a way where every one of them are unique and really catches your attention, especially Nadeshiko and Rin, who are 2 of the main characters of the show. These 2 characters really show great chemistry together as both of them help each other out, making their camp fun and exciting. \n\n
Enjoyment: 10\n
Personally, I enjoyed the anime a ton lot, as it really managed to, using camping as the main plot, which may seem to be a turn off due to the effort and time required in the preparation, to appeal to the audience. At the end of the day, it really changed my views on camping into a more positive one. Being able to enjoy the adventures as if you are with them was one of the few unique experiences the anime managed to let the audience have.\n\n
Overall, this series is a brilliant 9 out of a 10.

There aren't much story in this show but knowledge for camping (some for Japan campsite only). It is a relaxing anime mainly about 1...2...4...5...6...err I guess is 6 girls [It was solo camp to 2 ppl camp to 4 people and 5th joined then teacher...] camping...
The story is mainly showing the change of MC from a girl who enjoy solo camping [hates camping with others] to a girl who join group camping. 
Not much story line in it. Mainly show different venue of camping (mostly around Mt Fuji) and the life of that few girls.
The show is really relaxing (including the song) and sometimes veryfunny. And I think they spell the name wrongly not yuru camp but yuri camp XP.\n\n
If you are looking for relaxing/yuri/camping knowledge/Mt Fuji view location then this is your type of anime.

Do you want to take a break from the stress of the real world? Want something that will warm your heart? Something cute yet with a few lessons?
Then Yuru Camp△ is for you!
The story is totally laid back and tries to let you see the wonders of camping, either solo (thanks to Shimarin) or in good company (thanks to the Outdoor Activities Club). It really soothes your mind and let you enjoy a cute slice of life.
The story itself even lets you know good recipes to enjoy while camping, to actually help you if you happen to decide to try it out!

I’m just going to start off with a little piece of advice. This anime is EXTREMELY chill. If you’re looking for the slightest bit of adrenaline rush then this isn’t the right one for you. However, if you’re looking for a heartwarming experience like you’ve never seen before then you’re just in the right place.
Story: Not much of a story; Rin is a student who likes to go solo camping in her free time in winter when no one else does so that she can get to enjoy the scenery and quiet all by herself. Nadeshiko meets her while she’s camping and the two becomefriends right away. Most of the episodes are either about camping or preparing for camping in a way or another. There aren’t many characters and there is no need. It’s just a warm, cosy marshmallow of an anime and that’s all it needs to be.



Art: the drawing style matches the intention of the anime as a whole. It doesn’t give the characters too much details or a distinguishable feel to their drawing. Yet, the scenery, the main focus, is way too beautiful it’s ridiculous. Most of the campsites are around Mount Fuji, but each has a beauty of its own.



Sound: This show isn’t too conversation-focused with most of the attention given to the atmosphere and that just makes it even more natural. At times, you’ll feel as if you’re sharing the experience with Rin and the others as if you were there which makes it all the more heartwarming.



Entertainment: I’ve definitely developed an interest in camping after this anime and might try it. This is just the right dose you need after an emotional anime like Violet Evergarden so it acted as a medicine in my Thursdays. I also got to learn a bunch of stuff even if trivial about how camping is, a bunch of dishes and how beautiful the scenery in Japan is. If you’re just about to start watching this, I’d recommend getting as comfortable as possible and a warm drink for maximum enjoyment.
