This series is one of the many Slice of Life (SoL) series that emerged in the winter of 2018. Anime with the premise of Cute Girls Doing Cute Things (CGDCT) which in this case the activity is camping in winter. This series I think is not just providing cute girls with funny behavior camping together, but the most gained from this series is the comfort in watching and educational elements about camping and outdoor activities are delivered completely.
STORY : 7/10
storyline in this series is the standard story on the SoL series. No significant story progress. Background as a high school student in one of theareas near Mount Fuji, each episode tells about various things around the fifth main character's camping activity. There were no conflict and no drama. The journey of the story was episodic with some characters going to a camping spot, enjoying the scenery, then returning home to plan where else they will go. Some episodes do not focus on camping like activities at school, shopping to outdoor stores and others. This moment that feels strange when looking at the characters in this series in 1 episode were not camping at all.. The thing that will be more we meet is the interaction between them and the properties of each character that strongly describes Cute Girls Doing Cute Things. The interactions that eventually collect them at the last camp on Episodes 11 and 12


DIRECTION : 9/10


The thing that makes this series so up and much watched is the comfort in watching this series. This series is very suitable to watch while sitting relaxed and drinking tea or coffee. Direction in this series is designed to make the audience comfortable viewing Mount Fuji scenery or just look at the smile of the characters when viewing the scene. Similarly, when a scene cooks or eats characters, I feel like I'm watching cooking anime than camping anime. The way the narrators explain each tutorial in this series is very complete. From start to set up tent, ignite firewood, to cooking. But because it is so complete, the narrative about the tutorials sometimes feels too long. The comedy shown is also very light but able to make us laugh very fast. As an SoL anime, storytelling in this series is executed well.


CHARACTER : 8/10

Cute Girls Doing Cute Things. Of course the girls in this series should be cute especially when they do camping. No significant character development. The only character development that was presented was when Shimarin who had always camped alone could accept that camping with many people can also be fun. The rest, every character remains on his cute character from beginning to end of series. Nadeshiko is plain but incredibly hyperactive, Shimarin who seems cold but when it's smiling makes your heart touched. Similarly Aoi, Chiaki, and Saitou are honestly their character is not too embedded in my memory. Each character is supported with a very good voice acting. Not surprisingly, the existence of VA such as Rie Takahashi and Nao Touyama there.


ART : 7/10

This anime is a series from Studio C-Station. Honestly I have never heard the studio and the anime series he made. In terms of character design and light color selection is perfect for SoL anime. The character design of this series reminds me of the Blend S series in the previous season. Probably because Yuru Camp Δ and Blend S are in the same manga magazine. But in adaptation to the animation media I have more execution on Blend S than this series. Animated execution feels like a low-budget animation. Some of the scenes are featured like a slide show. Even since the opening animation we can judge the quality of this series. 3D CG in the anime also feels very strange especially when showing Shimarin motorcycle. I do not know if this is because the studio is inexperienced or it's a little budget. But other than those things mentioned above, the other part I can still receive without disturbing me in enjoying this series. Art OK but animation still needs improvement. One thing that needs to be appreciated is how this series displays every beautiful scene seen by the characters. Starting from Mount Fuji to city lights at night. All presented well. So not only the characters who are amazed, but we also feel the beautiful scenery.


SOUND : 8/10

One of the things that make this series so comfortable to watch is the existence of the soundtrack. When the moment to see the scene will start then the soundtrack will begin to change the mood that was just normal to feel a sense of wonder something. The soundtrack in this series is also capable of supporting every conversation and comedy in this series. The whole soundtrack of this series seems very suitable to play while relaxing or maybe before we sleep. Because so comfortable every soundtrack to be heard. The opening song describes the passion for adventure or camping, but the ending song depicts the comfort coupled with the scene they are sleeping or sitting and watching the sun rise.


Overall, this series is very comfortable to watch, perfect for watching with the family at night while relaxing or drinking coffee. The educational aspect of camping and outdoor activities is well presented. There are still some problems from this series especially in terms of animation. But it will not make us lose the comfort shown by this anime.

Warmth.
Is the word I choose if I were to describe this show in just one word. It’s not particularly because it’s a winter season show and every single character seem to be wearing multilayered clothings and they’re camping in the middle of winter but because it manages to evoke a familiar warm and fuzzy feeling inside me. I can only feel calm watching this every week after a hard day at work. 
Imagine a situation where on that day your boss is shouting at you for no apparent reason and suddenly there’s piles upon piles of work given to you that needs to be doneby the end of the week, for sure you’d be stressed out to the maximum you’d want to quit as soon as possible. As the day end, you decided to take a walk at your nearest neighborhood park. There you can see birds chirping, dogs running, people having picnics smiling and laughing and then the wind catches the leaves on the trees and they fall on to the river stream. You look down on the leaves and watch a clear reflection of yourself. You’re unhappy not because of your own incompetency but it’s because other people are weighing down on you. That’s what creates the stress. Now look up around you and see why other people are smiling when you don’t. It’s because they appreciate the world around them and values mother nature above all else. They know that people can be annoying, cruel and non-sympathetic but they make the most out of what life can offer. \n\n
So don’t quit that job just yet. Take a leave or simply do it on the weekends, buy/rent a moped and go to the great outdoors. Go camping. Take a hike. Climb a mountain. Nature will help ease your pain. Bring a friend or two along if you’re feeling lonely. Hopefully, after that trip you return a rejuvenated man/woman with a new and positive outlook on life. If the boss is still yelling at you for no apparent reason, tell him/her to fuck off and quit so you can go on more camping trips.\n\n
That’s what I learned from this show. It makes we want to go camping every weekend. Great show. Can’t recommend it any more. Luckily, I’m still employed.

COMFY: The Anime
Yuru Camp, a show about camping that you watch in the comfort of your own home. A show you watch thinking "Hey, that looks like fun" and "I wanna try that too!" Only to realize that the harsh, cruel, world outside your bedroom is a living nightmare and you'd surely die the second you attempted such a feat.
STORY: A group of girls like to camp and bring you on their journey as they discover that camping with friends is a truly amazing experience. It's not much of a story but what they do with it is what matters most.
ART: The art in thisshow takes the idea of girls going camping and makes the most of it. BEAUTIFUL backgrounds and environments that feel like they were pictures taken from the very places they were based on! This shows art is amazing and really brings home the comfy feel of the anime. These girls look like they are living the dream and watching them makes me feel the same.


SOUND: Sounds like camping. 


CHARACTERS: Rin Shima and her trademark hair, Nadeshiko Kagamihara and her... uhh... cuteness. All the girls in this show are great. There's nothing else to really say, you should honestly just watch the show because you're in for a treat.


ENJOYMENT: SO MUCH ENJOYMENT


Overall: It's a very satisfying and comfy 9.


TL;DR - So comfy that I don't know why you bothered to read reviews for it. Just watch and feel amazed by the art and enjoy yourself.

This show is 10/10 for wholesomeness. MAL says I need to make a longer review than that but that is really all you need to know.
If you have ever been camping, you will find this anime perfectly gets to the essence of both the quiet peace of being alone in nature, and the camaraderie of going on a camping trip with friends. 
Yuru camp is on the slower side and I think it suits the show and subject perfectly. 
The music track works so well with the laid back spirit of the show.

They've done a brilliant job with this show. I feel like it does what it and the manga originally intended to do. It's peaceful and calming and when I was watching it, I certainly feel as such. No extra story, no extensive plot, no weird plot twists; just cute characters going camping. If you wanted more then don't watch slice of life. If you liked this show I'd recommend Yama no Susume. It's different but it certainly encourages one's outdoor spirit as much as Yuru Camp did.
I loved it. 
My mom loved it. 
It's hard to see that YOU won't like it.
Now only if wehad Mt. Fuji in America....

Story: Honestly it's a really nice story. You have Nadeshiko who becomes interested in camping after seeing Rin solo camping. Which results in her joining the Outdoors Club, which is basically just a camping club, and we get to see not only her but the other girls learn about camping, take on responsibilities in life, and become closer as friends.
I also showed this anime to a friend of mine who camps on a regular basis and he told me that most of the situations when it comes to Camping is accurate in this anime.
Art and Animation: I felt like the animation was simple whichis not a bad thing. It was really unique as well, I don't think I watched an anime before with this sort of animation and character design. It was really enjoyable. The background images were fantastic as well. I enjoyed how the camp sites were still frames and not animated. It actually made it feel more real.


Sound: I really enjoyed the OST for this anime. So much I bought the CD with every song on it. Super Enjoyable. Add in the fact that the Opening was probably the best opening of the season and the Ending was very nice to listen too.


Characters: The five main high school girls are so awesome. Rin and Ena had their close nit relationship while Chiaki and Aoi had theirs, Nadeshiko was the glue which brought all of them together which I really enjoyed. Add in Toba-Sensei and Sakura (Nadeshiko's older sister) and you really have one awesome cast of characters.


Enjoyment: I thoroughly enjoyed this anime. It's nice to not have to watch an anime and stress over "Is this person going to die" or "Please let my ship happen." No man just watching a nice slice of life anime is enough sometimes.


Overall: Overall I would consider this a Masterpiece of an anime when it comes to the slice of life genre. The fact that people not only in Japan but all over the world are being inspired to go outdoors after watching this anime is awesome. Oh yeah...AND IN THE WINTER TOO!!!

Yuru Camp, otherwise known as Laid Back Camp has ended today. Laid Back Camp is about cute girls going camping. Specifically Winter camping. That is all for the most part. With this show, all you get is cute girls and some camping tips. This is the type of anime that is trying to teach you things through the medium of cute girls, which I am completely down with. Although, while the girls do their job so much better then I normally see in moe shows, I don't much care about the camping aspect of the show. To be honest, I can't find the concept anymore boring. I'm sure it might be exciting/informative for someone who is interested/experienced in camping. Its just not for me. Again, I'm watching this for cute girls. I must make a comment about background art, which in this show is stunning. It enhances the likeness camping aspect for the show tenfold, especially with its depiction of Mount Fugi. The animation is nothing to speak of, not that it needs to be. Music is very good for the atmosphere its depicting. Very chill, almost laid back. The OP and ED simulate that well.  This show, to me, is a 5 out of 10. I didn't enjoy this show very much, but I'm sure others would. I can recommend this to anyone and everyone. I rarely gives out 10's, and if I do, it is usually for subjective reasons of personal preference, so bear that in mind.
Story 8/10 - Considering the theme, it is pretty good.. Well executed from opening, middle, and conclusion for each episode. I rate the consistency of episode progression from an objective standpoint, since a standard for scene progression is closer to a science in the industry.
Art 9/10 - There are some scenes that are beautifully drawn, and that made me want to get out and go explore nature. However, there are also some less than stellar scenes that look like the drawings were draftedon a budget or during crunch time, so I take one point off. 


Sound 10/10 - When an anime gets this right, for many people, it can absolutely impact the entire atmosphere and memorability that a show provides. Happily enough, Yuru Camp pulls off the sound excellently, and it ends up conveying a very positive and happy mood in the OP, which engages the viewer and gets them excited to tag along for an adventure. Then at the end of the episode, the ED chosen is a very relaxing song that you might imagine yourself lounging back to under dim lights before peacefully going to sleep after a long days adventure filled with good memories. 


Character 8/10 - The sort of moe archetypes you find in Yuru Camp are just that, common archetypes. However, they fit perfectly in theme with the anime, so it's hard to argue the need to reinvent the wheel when it spins just fine. The uncommon anime settings that the characters are placed in (camping!), however, gives their archetypal nature some much appreciated diversity that prevents the characters from coming across as a redundant cliche.


Enjoyment 10/10 - This is where I express my subjective take. I love a variety of genre's in Anime, and generic Moe is... One of those genre's that I'm not a huge fan of. However, I've always had a soft spot for Slice of Life and unconventional themes in Animation, and that's what this anime is, with it's uplifting theme of hopeful, joyous happiness that is reminiscent of youthful ignorance and optimism. Truly, it's a show that depicts a completely unprejudiced, non-judging, peaceful world devoid of any of the hardships that are prevalent in real life, and "camping" is the metaphorical vehicle used to express the optimism, peacefulness, wonder, and exploration of the unknown in a positive, fun light.


Overall 10/10 - The show acted as a temporary cure/escape from my long term, high functioning depression. It is incredible at lifting spirit and was a joy to watch. Other users are not far off in calling this anime therapeutic. 


Lastly, I could have just as easily given this anime an 8/10, which I'd say is closer to an objective score. However... You know, sentiment and all. I like to round up the score to reflect the individual impact the show had on me as a viewer, and hopefully to encourage others to look past some of the meta number crunching and go with what they feel they will enjoy.

Quick summary of the review : 
Yuru Camp conveys really well the feeling of camping : the great OST and sound effects have a huge part in this, the rest is with the details they put into the sceneries and camping scenes. You might even actually learn a thing or two about camping. It's a show for relaxing yourself and for that it's ridiculously good.
Story :
There isn't much to say about the story, it really isn't the point of watching Yuru Camp
Art :
The art, while not outstanding, is pretty solid. They paid special attention to all scenes where camping was involved, and all of thecamping spots are beautiful\n\n
Sound :\n
The sound ambience of this anime is INSANELY good. The OST alone make you feel comfy and like you are in the middle of camping somewhere. They also made efforts in the sound effects related to camping and it greatly contributes to building the overall ambience of Yuru Camp.\n\n
Character :\n
Again, there isn't much to say about the characters. You can classify this show as "cute girls doing cute things", moe or whatever similar. And for that particular field it's good, all the girls have differents personnalities and are not redundant.\n\n
Enjoyment :\n
Now, this is where all the interest is : This anime just show girls camping around various places, talking about it and making preparations for it. It properly build an atmosphere because they made efforts in drawing the camping spots and the sceneries, and they show things that you would probably do when camping (setting up your tent and installing yourself, enjoying the scenery, preparing and eating food...). But the real strength of Yuru Camp lies in its amazing sound ambience : the OST is incredibly fitting (and is excellent) and the sound effects are pretty immersive (cracking sound of wood on fire, sounds of setting up the camp, the sounds of manipulating tools for cooking...). These convey REALLY well the camping aura of the show and create a convincing atmosphere.\n
They took advantage of the fact that Nadeko is a complete beginner in camping to give us various informations about camping, and you may learn things about camping with Yuru Camp. While it's not extraordinary, it's a nice addition. However keep in mind that this anime primary goal isn't being educational.\n\n
If you are into moe, you will surely enjoy Yuru Camp. If you are not, don't let it prevent you to watch it, because it's not all about that. It's a comfy show that you watch to become comfy yourself.\n
This show actually made me want to go camping myself.

Fanservice: There is could hot springs episodes nothing is shown except a little cleavage other than no other fan service. 


Negatives:


The second one is I feel like the outdoor club is sort of pushed to the side in this anime since they focus on rin-chan and Naskido for the 6 episodes so they less memorable even though they were main characters.


The third thing is there are drinking and mention of beer or wine in the anime so beware of that. 


conclusion:  Other than those issues I brought up I think this incredible anime that fairly clean with maybe few curse words here and there but not something be concerned with. So if looking for some calming and relaxing then this the anime for you.  


Plus I learned this these campsites are actual real locations in Japan you visit so be sure to check them out.

This review has a summed up review at the top without any spoilers and a bigger review with spoilers after
Non-spoiler review:
Plot: 9; Really realistic plot. But would have liked to see other parts of the characters lives.
Visuals: 10: Honestly, I loved it. The character style worked really good and the backgrounds were amazing. 
Music: 9; Many were forgettable, but worked excellently well with the tone of the show.
Characters: 9; Has many great characters, but a few predictable and one-sided ones (but they were not in a big part of the show)
Enjoyment: 10; Super relaxing, pretty funny and cute
Overall: 9
Spoiler review:
Plot:
I thought it was very good.It was realistic, funny and just great in general. But I have two complaints. The first one is that the reactions that the characters get when eating something feel very overexaggerated. Second, I would have liked to see other parts of the characters lives and not just camping. I mean, it's good that they actually camp in the show, *cough* K-on *cough*, but they barely show anything else. BTW, they actually made camping very appealing. good job! \n
Edit: I just remembered. That last scene is (I think) exactly the same as the first one. Every single shot.\n\n
Visuals:\n
I loved it. The art style is great and the backgrounds were fantastic. A good anime for backgrounds\n\n
Music:\n
OP: I really liked it, but it didn't really fit the tone of the series in my opinion\n
ED: Loved it, fit perfectly with the tone\n
The rest of the music: Pretty forgettable but with amazingly well with the tone of the show. \n\n
Characters: I love Rin Shima. She felt VERY realistic and I could relate to her many times. The rest were also great. Nadeshiko may seem one-sided (that's what I thought she wouöd be) but she wasn't. Next, Chiaki. I didn't like her the first time watching this show. I thought she was weird and not funny. But this time I actually really liked her. She wasn't one-sided or predictable and I actually found her pretty funny sometimes. Aoi was as cute as ever. Then we had Ena, who I didn't really like. She was very one-sided. But she wasn't a big part of the show so it didn't affect the characters much. Then we have Toba which I found very predictable, especially in the last two episodes. But again, she wasn't a big part of the show. I just have one more character to talk about. She was probably my second favorite character. Nadeshiko's sister Sakura. She felt very realistic. I'm not saying that Nadeshiko and her sister didn't get along, but they weren't the usual sibling characters in an anime. \n\n
Enjoyment: It was relaxing, funny, cute. What more can I say?\n\n
Overall: 9

Yuru Camp gathers people around the campfire, immersing them in nature and good feelings. This is the kind of anime that can help relieve a lot stress—especially after a hard day’s work. Some may even categorize it as a “healing anime.” From its cozy visuals of nature to its cute, lovable characters, Yuru Camp takes the simple concept of camping with friends and transforms it into an anime that emits a relaxing sensation in every episode. With this in mind, this review will demonstrate why Yuru Camp is a must watch for those looking for a good feel-good anime.
Because Yuru Camp is a laid backanime, it does not have a detailed plot. It simply follows the days in the life of its characters as they do camp related things. Instead of a complex story, the anime presents camping sequences that produce a relaxing feeling and light-hearted, comedic scenes that manage to give good laughs. By not having a complex story, the anime takes on a relaxing tone which encourages people to take life easy and absorb the beauty of nature through Yuru Camp. 


Although the anime does not have a complex story, Yuru Camp does have a lovely bunch of characters. Each of the characters has their own unique personalities which makes them memorable and adds life to the anime. Interestingly, the cast is introduced in a way such that the audience “befriends” the characters, so to speak. The viewer meets the characters and just starts hanging out with them as friends. Consequently, the characters possess some ambiguity because the anime does not answer the question: “How did the Yuru Camp girls get into camping in the first place?” This fact alienates the characters from the audience. But, this would be an important case if the anime develops some sort of plot later. 


Aside from its characters, Yuru Camp’s artwork involves immersive backgrounds and landscapes that bring the Japanese natural sceneries to life. This beautiful art evokes a relaxing feeling similar to the feeling of seeing a breathtaking view from a mountaintop. The character designs are cute and stay true to the manga but, do not take away any realism from the backgrounds. In short, the anime has awesome art which immerses the audience into the world of Yuru Camp. As a result, the artwork is indeed an essential quality that makes Yuru Camp a relaxing watch.


To embellish the art, Yuru Camp’s music creates the anime’s country-side atmosphere that fits the overall camping theme very well. The music from acoustic guitars, violins, and the occasional banjo provides the country-side feeling which enhances the beauty of nature depicted in the anime. In a sense, the music evokes a feeling that is comparable to strolling in a park or hiking a nature trail with friends and family. Such is the nature of Yuru Camp’s music which is ideal for a camping anime.


Upon evaluation, Yuru Camp proves to be a good feel-good anime that induces a relaxing feeling through its art, soundtrack, and characters. This anime relaxes the mind and gives audiences a chance to take a walk in nature without having to go out. But, on the other hand, Yuru Camp does inspire people to go outside once in a while to enjoy nature.

Cute girls doing camping things? Yuru Camp is one of the gems I found last winter season. It tells the story of the members of the Outdoor activities club, the solo camper Shima Rin and lastly the clueless Nadeshiko who happens to get involved due to her clumsiness.
The plot is pretty straightforward and it involves a lot of information about camping. Using narratives and other presentations that makes it easier to understand for those who haven't really tried going out to do this kind of activity.
With great art illustration of the landscapes it tends to give you the feel to want to go camping. Combinedwith the upbeat opening song that sets the mood to get up and go there, if you know what I mean. Topping it off with all diverse but likable personalities of each characters that makes this series a mix of all possible good things to happen. And I wasn't wrong.


Overall, Yuru Camp is a wholesome, heartwarming and relaxing series. If you want to watch something with your family or just enjoy a laid back anime this is for you.


Sometimes we all need to enjoy the simpler things in life. Recommended!

TL;DR: Any anime that has non-humans "talking" is going to score moar points with me. "The pine cone." "hi there." "A chestnut." "yo."
Two words I've heard to describe this anime that were very very good: Wholesome, and Practical. I'd add Hilarious as well.
While this is about how five girls eventually go on a winter camping trip together, central to that journey are the journeys of Rinand Nadeshiko. You couldn't imagine a couple of polar opposites: Rin, the quiet, thoughtful, introverted solo camper girl (but loves a good joke like anyone else), very "cat-like" in anime parlance, contrasted with Nadeshiko, the hyper-extroverted, easily distracted, silly girl with the bottomless appetite, very "puppy-like". Together, they develop some really good chemistry, and the gags they turn out together always put a smile on my face.


Those who have read the manga may notice that the character designs only resemble the originals. Personally, I like them, as they lend themselves to expressiveness and just plain look "anime". Perhaps the only exception to that is Aoi's design, but I guess they wanted a diversity of... endowment. The set backgrounds, especially the campgrounds, combine photorealism with the bright saturated tones of anime. For an unknown studio, pulling off this level of quality is quite the accomplishment.


In many shows, the soundtrack does one of two things: It shows off as one of the stars (think Yoko Kanno or Naoki Sato, among others), or it blends into the background. The soundtrack of Yuru Camp is like a companion, expressing perfectly what's on screen, going "Wow!" when you do with a glorious sunrise, and giving you a nice folksy background otherwise with bluegrass instruments. Any track that effectively uses kazoos and old school radio sound effect instruments during "fun time" is a good one, I think. Each campground has its own theme track, though some bits and pieces are repeated elsewhere in similar scenes. The soundtrack is so good, I'm using it as background music for when I work and when I play Minecraft. The opening and closing credits music is like the characters of Nadeshiko and Rin: one cheerful (almost Jackson Five-like), and the other relaxed. A very good complement to the show.


Anyone can watch this anime, even to just kick back and snooze. Aside from "Miss Chug"'s... habit and a few bathing scenes, this is a very G/PG-rated anime. Seriously, for the most part you can watch with the kiddos, it's that wholesome.


Or take notes during the scenes reminiscent of Goofy's "How To" videos (with minimal klutz factor) and learn all about city slicker camping in Japan. Perhaps if there's a next series, they'll include basic survival skills like what to do when you want a fire but your matches are all wet and you're out of lighter fluid. The practicality of the show even extends to rough estimates of the cost of quality camping gear. And lest anyone think the girls are doing nothing but set fires and drink cocoa, they also participate in their own experiments MythBusters style. Those are some of the funniest moments on the show.


The various camping meals, while largely made of bought rather than foraged ingredients, always made me hungry. But the fact that the enjoyment in a camping situation is very different plays to this show's greatest strength: it doesn't just go nuts with the girls' reactions to what's happening, it also steps back and lets you take in and enjoy the view. At times it'll choose that moment to deliver a well-timed punch line, so that's fun too.


Finally, without spoiling the plot, I absolutely loved how the finale "bookended" the first episode, calling back what happened before with some variations.

tl;dr: Comfy, cute, camping. A super light hearted, easy going anime that is perfect for people who like cute girls or camping.
Story: 8/10
For the kind of show that Yuru Camp is, I went expecting small, short stories per episode with not muc interconnected story arcs. I got what I expected all wrapped up in a nice, evenly paced show. It doesn't try to bog itself down with trying to create some major conflict or character development at the end of the show. It paces itself well to show the small growths of each character and the lives they live. It felt very natural and organic.As I am loathed to use random words to describe a show, Yuru Camp's story was comfy af. Its very strongly paced but nothing to really push it into that 9 or 10 category.


Art: 8/10

I love it when a show's art style fits the shows central theme and purpose. For a story that's focused on camping and friendship, the bright happy tones of the show really fits this show to a T. The color palette and the animations really sell the bright, bubbly feel of the whole show.

Also the background picturesque depictions of the camp grounds and Mount Fuji are really beautiful. I think the studio did a good job of getting just the right angle in and having it drawn from all different angles too. Overall a solid job in the art and animation department. (Bonus points for a creative and fun OP)


Sound: 7/10

I would say its the weakest portion of the whole show but that's not saying much given how great this show was overall. The OP and ED are very defining to the themes of the show with the bright bubbly OP that is contradictory to the mellow and chill ED. They both perfectly describe the show: both happy and laid back. The rest of the sound I have no complains about but nor was I blown away by them. So its an easy 7/10


Character: 8/10

Maybe it was because this was just another cute girls doing cute things show but I really appreciated the characters in this show. Nadeshiko annoyed me as this super annoying and obnoxious character, the typical main character as you will. However, as we continued onward she really grew on me throughout the show as she did for Rin and the rest of the club. Her bright and happy nature really livened up the show which really fit her character and purpose for her being on this show.

Rin on the other hands plays as the more mellow character who highly contrasts Nadeshiko. Her solo demeanor and the way she carriers herself all the way to the end of the show is simply refreshing to see. The writers didn't forcefully give her a characterization arc just because she's the cool and silent type. I also relate to Saitou on a spiritual level of being able to sleep in until past noon when given the opportunity.


Enjoyment and Overall:

Man this show was amazing. I loved almost every aspect of it but its far from being on of my top favorites. It does everything well but not perfectly if you get what I mean. I strongly recommend this for anyone who likes moe/cute girl shows as it will deliver. You should also watch it if you like camping. It's always interesting to see how other countries camping culture/rules are different than the ones back in America. Overall 8/10 but I highly recommend it none the less.

This. Anime. Is. Beautiful. The story of the anime has development and character goals. The art is also amazing, the scenes are beautiful animated and colorful. The music in this anime is beautiful. All songs in the anime are amazing, and the whole soundtrack makes me feel comfy. The characters are amazing. These characters are full of emotion, and I feel joy and comfort when the characters reach their goal. Overall, this anime is amazing. This anime has achieved pure comfyness and has gained the honor of being one of my favorites. I recommend this anime to anyone who is interested in getting into anime,or is looking for something comforting.

What happens when you combine Cute Girls with character, Fantastically animated Background shots, realistically drawn locations, actual recipes you can make while camping,  and calming soothing music? You get Yuru Camp. I completely understand this Anime isn't for everyone. This is an Iyshikei (Healing) anime, meaning it supposed to soothe or calm people watching it, man does it ever. Its slow pace and lack of action tho might turn off those who like the frenetic pace of a My Hero Academia or Darling in the Franxx.
The story starts with a character named Rin Shima, a gentle soul who loves books and the outdoors. Sheis a solo camper meaning she goes to locations by herself and takes in the peace and quiet alone. Contrast that with Nadeshiko Kagamihara the other main character whom she meets at Lake Motosko, she is a free spirit, loud, knows nothing about camping but wanted to take in the picturesque view of Mt. Fuji. The anime then in 12 episodes tells the story of how the act of camping and learning about how, bonds these two characters together. Throw in great side characters, a teacher (later adviser) who drinks in excess while camping and it forms a wonderful comfy show you can sit and relax to with some cocoa or put on right before sleeping as the ED song is almost like a lullaby. \n\n
10/10 for me wonderful show with great attention to detail and a great advertisement for Yamanashi Prefecture should anyone ever want to go camping in the Fall in Japan.

Yuru Camp is the epitome of Slice of Life about something most anime fans will never do but will love it nevertheless.
Like Long Riders! was about learning how to enjoy driving a bike this one was about camping. Both had some rookie advice about stuff you must have or could have while others had more complex information about stuff both things. 
This one had a minor sub-plot on food-porn. Each time they made outdoor food I thought WHY do I have a kitchen if I could only a mini-stove and do it all? It's sad...
Lets be real, Yuru Camp is way better and the ratingon MAL proves it. The art and animation are way better. The characters as well. In this one we have pro Shina Rin while on Long Riders you had 3/4 girls but both had a clueless girl Nadeshiko in this one and Ami in the other one. This also follows a trend I enjoy about anime trying to educate anime fans about stuff we don't even care.. or think we don't - Hinako Note made about a trope of Theatre, Urara Meirochou about a fictionalize divining school, Stella no Mahou  about a computer company, Konohana Kitan & Kabuki-bu about Kabuki.


Don't get me wrong - it's interesting that anime can make this stuff a shows us that those things can be good. Geez I wanna go camping and I hate bugs. 


So why the high rating? Well it's a blend of very Cute Girls doing Cute Things with incredible landscapes you could have on your PC, interesting music. It's relaxing and watching before bed will grant you passage to nightmare-zone free zone. I smile while I watch this anime. 


And the food! 


If you want to relax, explore and watch do stuff you either don't feel confortably doing OR if you love it and do it this anime is to you. Slice of Life to the fullest.

Slice of Life Cute Girls Doing Cute Things show all follow the same formula. You take some sort of hobby that's niche, but not too niche, and you have a bunch of cute girls going to school, eating food, and occasionally doing that hobby. When you see complaints about the CGDCT "genre", that's why - they're all the same show with slightly different characters and a slightly different premise, with no real substance beneath it.
Laid-Back Camp seems to fit that description on the surface, but this really is a shining gem in the genre. Why it escapes the bog of mediocre CGDCT can be boileddown to what are, in my opinion, its two main strengths.


First and foremost, the majority of the focus is on the premise of camping. This is actually a show about cute girls *camping*, as opposed to your K-On!s of the world, which is about *cute girls* in a band. The idea of a slice of life actually focusing on the premise or the gimmick is not uncommon, of course. Encouragement of Climb is both a recent and similar example of one that did it well.


What pulls Laid-Back Camp ahead of Encouragement of Climb is its second strength - its cast. Usually the process of filling out a cast of Cute Girls is picking four or five of the main archetypes in the genre and make them all friends. While Nadeshiko could easily be classified as your Genki Girl, Rin is a very complex and unique character, which you could honestly just sum up as being a very realistic introvert - a little standoffish, but is easily able to make and maintain a couple close friendships, and is very passionate about the things she likes.


Beyond just Rin being a good character, the whole cast is less defined by their own personality quirks and more defined by their unique relationships with each other. You have a core cast of five, but they're not just some group of close friends - they all have different relationships with every other character in that cast. Old friends, new friends, clubmates, classmates who don't really interact much. By the time episode 11 rolls around, one of the five main characters very reasonably still doesn't even know everyone's full name.


But ultimately even all of that is just detail - the substance beneath the main draw. And the main draw is a nice, relaxing story with beautiful scenery. Even if you don't care about the attention to detail and nuances in the actual camping activity or the character building, you're still left with a wonderfully peaceful show to just help you full of charm and relaxation.

Story - 7
I'm giving Yuru Camp a 7 for story because it's not exactly a plot-heavy anime. It's an iyashikei, it's a comfy SoL, if you want something plot heavy with deep thematic meaning you're not really gonna like Yuru Camp.
Art - 10
Simply put, this show is beautiful. The character designs are all unique and memorable, the backgrounds are gorgeous and the scenery is taken from real life locations.
Sound - 10 
The OP and ED are both catchy (as well as being good to look at). The background music fits the tone of the series perfectly. Especially, as I dubbed it, "The Nadeshiko shenanigans banjo"


Character - 10


There isn't a character in this series I dislike. Everyone from the one-episode side characters to (and especially) the two mains are likable. In any other anime any one of the main characters could be easy "best girl" candidates, and it really speaks to how lovable both Nadeshiko and Rin-chan are that they're both the clear favorites in this show.


Enjoyment - 10


This show is comfy, the fact that it's comfy is practically a meme. It's a perfect anime to sit down with after a long, hard day and just, relax. There's no grand, world ending problem, there's no melodrama or love triangles. You want to relax, turn this show on.


Overall - 10


At the end of the series I debated whether or not to give it a 9 or a 10, but, in the end I decided to give this a 10 "masterpiece" score. Why? Simply put, this show is an Iyashikei masterpiece.

This series serves one major role and that is to be a healing/relaxing series to make the viewer smile, for which it does an amazing job. It is a CGDCT series about a group of high school friends sharing in their enjoyment of camping.
There is no major story arcs or character development but instead the "story" (a loose usage of the word) is more focused on character interactions in different camping settings. It also acts a educational series of sorts as a narrator voices over parts to explain basics on camping as in fire starting, tent set up, cooking, site rules, etc. 
While the characteranimations are nothing to be overly impressed about, they are also not corner cut or look cheap. Where the series really shines visually is in the backgrounds and landscape view shots of camp sites and areas around Mt. Fuji. 


The OP and ED songs are uplifting and fit the series well. The OP can be a bit catchy but doesn't stand out too much. The voice actors (Japanese as no English dub available at this time) do a great job as they each voice their character's personalities perfectly.


The characters play off each other very well and each one fits their role. They can be stereotypical for a CGDCT series but they never reach the point of being over-the-top that plague the genre. They act very down to earth with only occasional moments of minor absurdity that supply the series its humor.


The series humor is a  not a laugh out loud humor but instead designed to leave a smile with the occasional joke causing a light chuckle. There is only one emotion this series is meant to cause and that is happiness.


Personally I used this series as a pick-me-up, saving each episode's viewing as to end a bad day on a happy note or to end viewings of more story driven/emotional series to wind down.


Similar Series: Non Non Biyoro, Sweetness and Lightning

Very nice anime if all you want to do is relax, certainly one of the best animes in the healing genre
Especially great if you camp yourself, plenty to relate to.
The animation and art style is great and nice to look at
The sound design is brilliant and really adds something to any given scene
Some well timed and quirky jokes in the mix
The story is very straightforward and easy to follow, pretty much just gets straight to the camping, which is either ideal or a deal breaker depending on who you are
The characters are interesting and certainly go with the overall vibe of the series, Nadeshiko standsout particularly well among the cast of characters for being so quirky and energetic\n\n
All in all if your into this sort of slice of life comedy or just want to relax this is the anime for you

After seeing exactly half of this anime I'm very pleased with what I got to enjoy. Slice of Life is one of my favourite genres. While there are many this season, Yuru Camp stands out with it's interesting premise.
The focus on camping is not the only thing that makes it stand out, but it's the main one for me. The visuals certainly help in making the experience relaxing, calming and comfortable. Music is very good and, most importantly, quite creative in terms of instruments used. I have to praise this anime for it's mastery in managing the mood. Yuru Camp does it spectacularly well, keepingevery episode calm but not boring. Occasional lively and funny bits kep me from getting bored too easily, while not disturbing the overall atmosphere of the show. 


For me, the Characters are likeable and well-written. There is introvertic Rin, who behaves like an actual introvert. This means that she has legit reasons for prefering to be alone while still being capable of spending time with other people and enjoying it. Then we have puppy-like Nadeshiko, who isn't just another cute, cheerful moe cutuot. Her character really shines whenever she interacts with Rin. Watching those two get closer is one of the highlights here, at least in my opinion . As for the other characters, they're not as enjoyable to watch. The supporting cast does well it's job of filling in the spaces between the two main girls when they're not together .  However, I have to admit they didn't impress me as much , except for Rin's friend. All the little situations with her were very fun to watch. She added some necessary insight into Rin's personality. Other than her, the remaining girls mainly support either Rin or Nadeshiko, rather than being particularly entertaing on their own. It's not that bad of a thing though. 


While there's still half of it left, I can already see it as probably the best Slice of Life anime this season. For now I rate it 8, but with a little bit of improvement in the latter half I may consider giving it a 9

Cute girls doing cute things, specifically talking about and going camping. Make no mistake: this is a very pleasant but not great series. There are no explosions, chase scenes or giant robots. There is a lot of beautiful scenery on about the level you would expect for a medium budget anime series. The artwork is adequate.
The story, such as it is through four episodes, revolves the four girls and only two of them are developed at all. Rin, the experienced camper, prefers camping alone in the winter (fewer people) and Nadeshiko, the novice camper, develop their friendship with the common bond of their love ofcamping. The other two friends could be anyone at all and it wouldn't make any difference to the story. The "story" is almost more about the joys of camping than it is about the characters.\n\n
This is a series that will sooth your nerves and leave you with a peaceful, easy feeling. And a few recipes appropriate for camping.

ok so I am just going to say this. this show is such a pleasant surprise. it was one of this shows I thought I am going to really hate and that's going to suck but it's a really good show. I don't see enough people talking about it and it's a shame. I think that because people already watches a lot of shows this season and that this ne didn't start earlier like another pleasant surprise a place further than the universe it doesn't get it's recognition while it's at least as good and one of the best this season. 
plot (7/10):
the plot ispretty good. I really like how they write it so far but I do find it lacking in a few points. I think that overall the plot is good but not amazing. now I just want to address that since the plot is about ccamping in the winter I cant help but feel it was an amazing choice to wait to winter season to get this show out as I feel it might not have been as good to me if it was released in the summer or spring. 

I also want to note some great things the show does which is to use a lot of texting to make the plot move and show the characters better and the fact that they simply explain camping things so well. I really like it.

I really thought about what to do in this category and I might be wrong or change my mind because this show's characters are great. I do however think they are lacking in a way that they are too similar. they are still a bit different but I hope the show will improve them. with that said I really love how they made the characters. they feel like actual goofy not too serious teenagers and honestly I really like the moments they are texting I their phones because it is so real (they even put some sorts of emojis in there). it also help building the characters and overall I found it great.

overall (8/10):

listen guys if you got time watch this. so far it's a really good show and one of my top 5 and maybe even 3 of the season. it is really something special that made me, one of the laziest people youll ever meet thinking about going to camp. it's a great show, I recommend it very much, and let's hope this show will keep being great.

Okay so first i will start with my rate. The anime get a 7/10. Why? Well, the anime is a really beautiful anime, it gives u a relax vibe and comfortable. The animations is really good for this kind of anime - just the cg of the vehicles that i don't liked - the OST is really good and i liked it. But this kind of show don't attracted me so many times is wasn't paying attention in the anime and just listening the OST - i rewatched this parts -, the narrator pissed me off, i think he wasn't necessary for the show, butok it didn't ruined it.  My last opinion its a nice anime to watch in the winter when u don't want to leave the bed and just want to chill drinking cocoa!

So nice and comfy and warm, like a nice tent and sleeping bag shielding you against the cool winter nights. 
Yuru Camp is absolutely a comfort food anime, providing pretty much nothing new when it comes to story, and likeable but not incredibly memorable characters, but doing so in just the right way to make you feel all happy on the inside. Seeing the characters travel around Kanto and Chubu discovering new places and camping out, eating tasty food, taking pretty pictures... it's great.
 I love how the characters aren't constantly connected, too; main character Rin is mostly separate from the rest of the castthroughout the series, and the energetic Nadeshiko often does her own thing as well. It makes the rare occurences when they do activities together all the more exciting, especially when all of them (except for Nadeshiko) aren't direct copypaste stereotypes from other slice-of-life mangas/animes.


The fact that the show is so educational on the ways to camp successfully by yourself or with others is icing on the cake, and has legitimately made me want to start camping as soon as the icy wastelands of Shimokita give way to better temperatures and better weather. A TV show inspiring me to take up outdoorsy activities seems insane but if I actually go through with it, that will mean Yuru Camp truly was something special.


Also, the OP and ED are both fantastic. The series soundtrack is also fantastic. Even if the animation is perfectly mediocre, the music in this show is top-tier.


So... no romance, no drama, just teenaged friends exploring Japan and having fun. That's what Yuru Camp is.

Yuru Camp or in English Laid Back Camp, is the most comfy anime of 2018. Yuru Camp is a cute girls doing cute things anime, so if your not into those then this win't be for you. If you are into that genre, and you like the camping, then this show is perfect for you. Through out Yuru camp you'll see cute girls going in detail about the different aspects that comes with camping. Setting up a tent, keeping warm, making food, it's all hear and it's surprisingly informative. It also really helps when the sound design teleports you to the outdoors. This isn't tosay that this is a camping documentary. There are characters... They just don't have any depth and really is just there to be cute, which I guess is fine, but I would of preferred less of a focus on the clubs dynamic since they didn't do anything with it. Honestly you'll probably get bored at certain points because even with this anime only being 12 episodes. This is not a show you binge, this is a show that you watch occasionally when you want to chill while watching a relaxing atmospheric show. Yuru camp isn't for everyone, but it's defiantly worth checking out if you're interested.

The "slice of life" genre has met its final form, and boy is it wonderful to see!
There is no narrative conflict anywhere in this series. No challenges to overcome, no skills to master, no crush to ask out. Simply a gang of lovely young people relaxing with camping, with nothing doki-doki ruining their good times.
Because sometimes, that is all you need to enjoy an anime. To just kick back and relax to a "cute girls doing cute things" series which doesn't rely on pink heart-shaped magic or high-pitched voices yelling "kawaii".
This succeeds so very well. You get engaged in the girls and their journeys, andare able to very closely immerse yourself in the cold winter air and their steaming food. You can focus on the feeling conveyed instead of following a narrative that will lead someplace. And when there is some kind of narrative - Shimarin travelling far or Nadeshiko discovering a piece of equipment - it is done in the lightest and most subtle way. The well-being of the characters is always the supreme priority for the audience, and it is a wonderful feeling to experience that principle.\n
I only wish there were more of these girls-just-want-to-have-fun-esqe stories out there!\n\n
Also, the visuals are absolutely gorgeous! The food they eat looks just like in a commercial, and the backdrops are almost hyper-realistic to capture the feel of cosiness. The moonlit Mt Fuji in the first episode was so amazing I could almost feel the cold air!\n\n
Perfect for watching before sleep or after a rough day! Heartbeat and blood pressure is guaranteed to drop!

If we talk about a slice of life anime, especially when it’s related to Iyashikei. It always gives us a good vibe from the simplicity of anime which is funny and moe, we don’t need to think anything hard and complex because Iyashikei itself is an anime genre that means “healing”. So, the Iyashikei anime is the anime that gives us anything relaxing atmosphere, less drama, even the perfect choice for your watchlist before bedtime. 
Yama no Susume did a job as an example of Iyashikei anime, where everything about the anime is a joy of mountain climbing, entertaining informative guide of how to climba mountain, and the story of each mountain(loli) climbers that gives you an amazing relaxing mood. The same thing goes to Yuru Camp, but they more oriented to camping 


Yuru Camp follows the story of the “campers”(ofc), that do camping activity(OFC). Starring the cutest anime lifeform who has a memeable hair, Shimarin. A basic cheery & energetic girl which sometimes she looks completely idiot, Nadeshiko. A girl with unique Japanese accent but at the same time, she is fanservice clickbait, Aoi. And…… the rest of them(lol, I don’t remember the others, but you just can look it at character list tho). Yeah, the show is all about camping, where they making foods, prepare a tent, and watch them talking in the night scenery which I don’t know why it’s relaxing to watch(apparently, the same thing goes on when I watch Nijisanji for hours)


What I like about this show is they just giving you a basic moefication camping show without giving anything weird about the show, like a kinda looked old girl but she is actually 9 years old or they were camping in the isekai world or whatever that is. It’s just giving you a real camping show(but ofc it has been moeficated). When I watch this show, I’m expecting like “Well, this is just a moeshit show, nothing special about it”. But actually, they give a special value because they put the moe “which is” definitely guaranteed to attract people for the first sight, an amazing beautiful scenery that perfectly drew to gain a comfy atmosphere, a real camp location and an information guide of how to camp which it made accurate and fun to watch, then it all combined into one show and it’s mixed very well. Also, the entire show filled with all comedy which makes the show more entertaining.


I don’t think I got of what I don’t like about this show. But, from their location, is all around of Mt Fuji, this need to be a concern because I think they are much popular camping sites beside around Mt Fuji, I think for the next season, I think they should put another…. no, they should put more popular camping site outside Mt Fuji. That would be more great, but depends on their story


Another plus point of this show is their catchy OP/ED songs, the show opens with SHINY DAYS by Asaka which give us an uplifting hype as the show begin to give the spirit of camping. Asaka did a great job for singing the hype song which matches with the anime atmosphere. And closed with Fuyubiyori by Eri Sasaki, which give us chills after all day of camping activities. This song is really comfy, even it’s perfect for your song to listen before bedtime


Overall, this anime is really family friendly, really good to watch. I probably suggest you if you want to camp, you don’t need book or anything, just watch Yuru Camp and you good to go, but keep in mind not everything in Yuru Camp you can do it (lol). I really loved everything from this anime, I’ll give this 8.5/10 for the joy of camping series.

Rin Shima is a regular off-season camper who enjoys the quiet time alone. While camping out at one of the popular five lakes around Mount Fuji, Lake Motosu one day she comes across cheery but also klutzy, overly naive Nadeshiko Kagamihara who just moved into the area nearby. Nadeshiko had just happened to sleep through the day near the camp site while trying to get a view of the mountain. Fortunately for her, she meets Rin and manages to get some food before calling someone to pick her up again. Mesmerised by the moonlit view of Mount Fuji, she is determined to go camping againand so she joins the Outdoors Club at her new school Motosu High where Rin just also happens to attend.


Art and animation itself is a bit average which is also the same for the backgrounds. Sometimes the character proportions can look a bit off and the 3D animation isn't well blended like other studios. A lot of the time places are completely deserted too so there isn't as much to render and animate. Quite a low budget show. Other than that, I think the only other thing stopping me from recommending this show is the setup which is your commonly used group of girls doing silly funny things.


Just like the title says, it's a very laid-back show based on a Manga of the same name. There's no drama unlike A Place Further Than The Universe, just a group of girls camping and chatting away leisurely with your usual funny reactions so it's a great show to wind down with. It's also a bit of an edutainment show where you end up learning about camping which is always a bonus when watching Anime. You'll also see this show's interpretation of Lake Suwa in Nagano which was also the same lake Lake Ito from Your Name was based on. There is the odd episode of fan service with your usual obligatory hot spring/bathing scene but that's about it. They're really brief and don't have any awkward actions or camera angles to spoil anything.


Beware of the blankie monsters.

***SHORT REVIEW***
Are u the type who loves exploring and loves to spend some time around travelling  witnessing the beauty of what nature has to offer?
If yes, then  look no further ,Yuru Camp aka Laid-back camp is just the anime you are looking for.
Lets jump into the reviewing part of this wonderful slice of life anime:
Story: 8/10
This story revolves around camping in general as the name of the anime suggests, this is the kind of anime where u sit back and enjoy what it has to offer.There is not much of a plot here it just about a group of girls who enjoy camping.Thereis also light hearted comedy and cutness which melts u away.


Art: 9/10

This anime has stunning visuals and the art style perfectly blends with genre of SOL.

each moment was a pleasure to watch and felt breath taking.The art makes u feel like you are actually right beside the characters experiencing the moment which was enough to give this anime a well deserved 9/10 in the art department.


Characters : 8/10

Typical moe characters doing their moe things which for the first time i felt it was CUTE and not overexagerated. There is not much character development here in this anime as it focuses on the enjoyment part which I'm glad they did.


Sound: 9/10

The background music perfectly synced into the moment and makes u feel warm and cozy inside. The ending and opening themes matched the theme of the anime and were good. Now coming to the voice of the characters, it was great,cute and refreshing to hear, therefore justifiying my rating of 9/10 in the sound department.


Enjoyment : 10/10

When you finish the anime, it will leave u with a "heartily content" look and u will look at the environment around you with an optimistic aproach and a bright smile (like this " :) " lol). So this will have to get a whooping 10/10 for giving me the pleasure of watching such an art peice. 


Overall: 9/10

This anime is all about the experience it gives while watching and not about the plot or characters.If u are like me who was fed up watching these typical harem , shonen and gore /horror and want escape this madness to watch something else,then this is exactly "your cup of tea". I personally would put it to the "must watch category" to all those casual anime watchers out there.


FINAL VERDICT : If these conditions apply ,then i gaurantee that you will have a refreshing experience so what are you waiting for just stop thinking and GO FOR IT!!

When the Winter Season started I did not have high hopes for it nor did I expect it to be bad or anything - I was only looking for your usual Cute Girls Doing Cute Things and lots of camping, but what I got instead was a sweet and lovely anime about friendship between girls with different personalities that do not have to do everything together, but can still have a strong bond.
Story - 8
What started as a simple camping anime developed into an anime about creating a friendship over marshmallows and grilled meat. Rin has always enjoyed solo-camping trip, but during one of heradventures she meets Nadeshiko and that's how Nadeshiko falls in love with camping. While Rin goes on camping trips with Nadeshiko and mostly on her own, Nadeshiko joins the Outdoor Club and discovers the joy of group camping. The entire anime is about the girls' friendship, although it doesn't follow the usual formula of girl doesn't like camping with others but then she changed her mind. Rin can go camping with other people and on her own, and Nadeshiko is not trying to change that.


Art - 8

The art style and character design are really cute, but I can't say there's anything special about it. However the nature shots are amazing. 


Sound - 8

It fits the story really well. It is soothing and relaxing.


Character - 10

Probably my favourite part, although Nadeshiko and Rin are the most developed from the bunch. What I liked the most was the emphasis on introvert-extrovert personalities and how they can go well together. 


Enjoyment - 10

I obviously loved it! But I discovered that if I watch too many episodes in a row then I get bored. But once a week or maybe twice, it's simply perfect to make my week better.


Overall - 9

It is a great anime if you are looking for an anime that doesn't have a lot of action, but it's all about nature, food and the little pleasures of life.
